Text

CHAPTER I. [I]0-i am [an old woman]299-an old woman now , and things are very different to what they were in [my]0-i youth . Then [we]300-we , who travelled , travelled in [coaches]301-coaches , carrying six inside , and making a two days ’ journey out of what [people]302-people now go over in a couple of hours with a whizz and a flash , and a screaming whistle , enough to deafen one . Then letters came in but three times a week : indeed , in [some places in [Scotland]1-scotland where [I]0-i have stayed]303-some places in scotland where i have stayed when [I]0-i was [a girl]304-a girl , the post came in but once a month;—but letters were letters then ; and [we]300-we made great prizes of them , and read them and studied them like books . Now the post comes rattling in twice a day , bringing short jerky notes , some without beginning or end , but just a little sharp sentence , which [well - bred folks]305-well - bred folks would think too abrupt to be spoken . Well , well ! [they]306-they may all be improvements,—I dare say [they]306-they are ; but [you]307-you will never meet with [a Lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]308-a lady ludlow in these days . [I]0-i will try and tell [you]307-you about [her]308-a lady ludlow . It is no story : it has , as [I]0-i said , neither beginning , middle , nor end . [[My]0-i father]309-my father was [a poor clergyman]310-a poor clergyman with [a large family]311-a large family . [[My]0-i mother]312-my mother was always said to have good blood in [her]312-my mother veins ; and when [she]312-my mother wanted to maintain [her]312-my mother position with [the people]313-the people [she]312-my mother was thrown [among,—principally rich democratic manufacturers]314-among,—principally rich democratic manufacturers , all for liberty and the French Revolution,—she would put on a pair of ruffles , trimmed with real old English point , very much darned to be sure,—but which could not be bought new for love or money , as the art of making it was lost years before . These ruffles showed , as [she]312-my mother said , that [[her]312-my mother ancestors]315-her ancestors had been [Somebodies]316-somebodies , when [the grandfathers of [the rich folk]318-the rich folk , who now looked down upon [her]312-my mother]317-the grandfathers of the rich folk , who now looked down upon her , had been [Nobodies,—if]319-nobodies,—if , indeed , [they]318-the rich folk had [any grandfathers at all]320-any grandfathers at all . [I]0-i do n’t know whether [any one out of [[our]322-our own family]323-our own family]321-any one out of our own family ever noticed these ruffles,—but [we]322-our were all taught as [children]324-children to feel rather proud when [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother put them on , and to hold up [our]322-our heads as became [the descendants of [the lady who had first possessed the lace]327-the lady who had first possessed the lace]326-the descendants of the lady who had first possessed the lace . Not but what [[my]0-i dear father]328-my dear father often told [us]322-our that pride was a great sin ; [we]322-our were never allowed to be proud of anything but [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother ’s ruffles : and [she]312-my mother was so innocently happy when [she]312-my mother put them on,—often , [poor dear creature]330-poor dear creature , to a very worn and threadbare gown,—that [I]0-i still think , even after all [my]0-i experience of life , they were a blessing to [the family]331-the family . [You]332-you will think that [I]0-i am wandering away from [[my]0-i [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]333-my lady ludlow . Not at all . The Lady who had owned the lace , [Ursula Hanbury]93-ursula hanbury , was [a common ancestress of both [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother and [[my]0-i Lady]336-my lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]334-a common ancestress of both my mother and my lady ludlow . And so it fell out , that when [[my]0-i poor father]337-my poor father died , and [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother was sorely pressed to know what to do with [[her]312-my mother nine children]339-her nine children , and looked far and wide for signs of willingness to help , [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow sent [her]92-lady ludlow a letter , proffering aid and assistance . [I]0-i see that letter now : a large sheet of thick yellow paper , with a straight broad margin left on the left - hand side of the delicate Italian writing,—writing which contained far more in the same space of paper than all the sloping , or masculine hand - writings of the present day . It was sealed with a coat - of - arms,—a lozenge,—for [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow was [a widow]340-a widow . [[My]0-i mother]312-my mother made [us]342-us notice the motto , “ Foy et Loy , ”[312-my mother] and told [us]342-us where to look for the quarterings of [the Hanbury arms]343-the hanbury arms before [she]312-my mother opened the letter . Indeed , [I]0-i think [she]312-my mother was rather afraid of what the contents might be ; for , as [I]0-i have said , in [her]312-my mother anxious love for [[her]312-my mother fatherless children]344-her fatherless children , [she]312-my mother had written to many people upon whom , to tell truly , [she]312-my mother had but little claim ; and [their]345-their cold , hard answers had many a time made [her]312-my mother cry , when [she]312-my mother thought none of [us]342-us were looking . [I]0-i do not even know if [she]312-my mother had ever seen [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow : all [I]0-i knew of [her]92-lady ludlow was that [she]92-lady ludlow was [a very grand lady]346-a very grand lady , whose grandmother had been [half - sister to [[my]0-i mother ’s great - grandmother]348-my mother ’s great - grandmother]347-half - sister to my mother ’s great - grandmother ; but of [her]92-lady ludlow character and circumstances [I]0-i had heard nothing , and [I]0-i doubt if [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother was acquainted with [them]350-them . [I]0-i looked over [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother ’s shoulder to read the letter ; it began , “ Dear [Cousin Margaret Dawson]94-margaret dawson , ”[0-i] and [I]0-i think [I]0-i felt hopeful from the moment [I]0-i saw those words . [She]312-my mother went on to say,—stay , [I]0-i think [I]0-i can remember the very words : ‘ [DEAR COUSIN MARGARET DAWSON,—I]95-dear cousin margaret dawson,—i have been much grieved to hear of the loss [you]95-dear cousin margaret dawson,—i have sustained in the death of [so good a husband , and so excellent a clergyman]352-so good a husband , and so excellent a clergyman as [I]0-i have always heard that [[my]0-i late cousin]353-my late cousin [Richard]96-richard was esteemed to be . ’ “ There ! ”[312-my mother] said [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother , laying [her]312-my mother finger on the passage , “ read that aloud to [the little ones]3038-the little ones . Let [them]3038-the little ones hear how [[their]3038-the little ones father]3039-their father ’s good report travelled far and wide , and how well [he]3039-their father is spoken of by [one whom [he]3039-their father never saw]3040-one whom he never saw . [COUSIN Richard]96-richard , how prettily [[her]3040-one whom he never saw ladyship]3041-her ladyship writes ! Go on , [Margaret]95-dear cousin margaret dawson,—i ! ”[312-my mother] [She]312-my mother wiped [her]312-my mother eyes as [she]312-my mother spoke : and laid [her]312-my mother fingers on [her]312-my mother lips , to still [[my]0-i little sister]355-my little sister , [Cecily]97-cecily , who , not understanding anything about the important letter , was beginning to talk and make a noise . ‘ [You]356-you say [you]356-you are left with [nine children]357-nine children . [I]0-i too should have had nine , if [mine]0-i had all lived . [I]0-i have none left but [Rudolph]98-rudolph , [the present [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow]358-the present lord ludlow . [He]98-rudolph is married , and lives , for the most part , in [London]2-london . But [I]0-i entertain [six young gentlewomen at [[my]0-i house at [Connington]3-connington]360-my house at connington , who are to [me]0-i as [daughters]361-daughters]359-six young gentlewomen at my house at connington , who are to me as daughters — save that , perhaps , [I]0-i restrict [them]359-six young gentlewomen at my house at connington , who are to me as daughters in certain indulgences in dress and diet that might be befitting in [young ladies of a higher rank , and of more probable wealth]362-young ladies of a higher rank , and of more probable wealth . [These young persons — all of condition]363-these young persons — all of condition , though out of means — are [[my]0-i constant companions]364-my constant companions , and [I]0-i strive to do [my]0-i duty as [a Christian lady]365-a christian lady towards [them]363-these young persons — all of condition . [One of [these young gentlewomen]367-these young gentlewomen]366-one of these young gentlewomen died ( at [[her]366-one of these young gentlewomen own home]368-her own home , whither [she]366-one of these young gentlewomen had gone upon a visit ) last May . Will [you]369-you do [me]0-i the favour to allow [[your]369-you eldest daughter]370-your eldest daughter to supply [her]370-your eldest daughter place in [[my]0-i household]371-my household ? [She]370-your eldest daughter is , as [I]0-i make out , about sixteen years of age . [She]370-your eldest daughter will find [[companions]372-companions here who are but a little older than [herself]370-your eldest daughter]373-companions here who are but a little older than herself . [I]0-i dress [[my]0-i young friends]374-my young friends [myself]0-i , and make each of [them]374-my young friends a small allowance for pocket - money . [They]374-my young friends have but few opportunities for matrimony , as [Connington]3-connington is far removed from [any town]375-any town . [The clergyman]376-the clergyman is [a deaf old widower]377-a deaf old widower ; [[my]0-i agent]378-my agent is married ; and as for [the neighbouring farmers]379-the neighbouring farmers , [they]379-the neighbouring farmers are , of course , below the notice of [the young gentlewomen under [my]0-i protection]380-the young gentlewomen under my protection . Still , if [any young woman]381-any young woman wishes to marry , and has conducted [herself]381-any young woman to [my]0-i satisfaction , [I]0-i give [her]381-any young woman a wedding dinner , [her]381-any young woman clothes , and [her]381-any young woman house - linen . And such as remain with [me]0-i to [my]0-i death , will find a small competency provided for [them]374-my young friends in [my]0-i will . [I]0-i reserve to [myself]0-i the option of paying [their]374-my young friends travelling expenses,—disliking [gadding women]382-gadding women , on the one hand ; on the other , not wishing by too long absence from [the family home]383-the family home to weaken natural ties . ‘ If [my]0-i proposal pleases [you]384-you and [[your]384-you daughter]385-your daughter — or rather , if it pleases [you]384-you , for [I]0-i trust [[your]384-you daughter]385-your daughter has been too well brought up to have a will in opposition to [yours]384-you — let [me]0-i know , [dear cousin [Margaret Dawson]94-margaret dawson]387-dear cousin margaret dawson , and [I]0-i will make arrangements for meeting [the young gentlewoman]388-the young gentlewoman at [Cavistock]4-cavistock , which is the nearest point to which [the coach]389-the coach will bring [her]385-your daughter . ’ [[My]0-i mother]312-my mother dropped the letter , and sat silent . “ [I]312-my mother shall not know what to do without [you]0-i , [Margaret]94-margaret dawson . ”[312-my mother] A moment before , like [a young untried girl]391-a young untried girl as [I]0-i was , [I]0-i had been pleased at the notion of seeing [a new place]392-a new place , and leading a new life . But now,—my [mother]393-mother ’s look of sorrow , and [the children]394-the children ’s cry of remonstrance : “ [Mother]393-mother ; [I]0-i wo n’t go , ”[0-i] [I]0-i said . “ Nay ! but [you]0-i had better , ”[312-my mother] replied [she]312-my mother , shaking [her]312-my mother head . “ [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow has much power . [She]92-lady ludlow can help [[your]0-i brothers]3043-your brothers . It will not do to slight [her]92-lady ludlow offer . ”[312-my mother] So [we]395-we accepted it , after much consultation . [We]395-we were rewarded,—or so [we]395-we thought,—for , afterwards , when [I]0-i came to know [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow , [I]0-i saw that [she]92-lady ludlow would have done [her]92-lady ludlow duty by [us]395-we , as helpless relations , however [we]395-we might have rejected [her]92-lady ludlow kindness,—by a presentation to [[Christ]101-christ ’s Hospital]396-christ ’s hospital for [one of [[my]0-i brothers]398-my brothers]397-one of my brothers . And this was how [I]0-i came to know [[my]0-i Lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]333-my lady ludlow . [I]0-i remember well the afternoon of [my]0-i arrival at [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court . [[Her]92-lady ludlow ladyship]3041-her ladyship had sent to meet [me]0-i at [the nearest post - town at which [the mail - coach]402-the mail - coach stopped]401-the nearest post - town at which the mail - coach stopped . There was [an old groom]403-an old groom inquiring for [me]0-i , [the ostler]404-the ostler said , if [my]0-i name was [Dawson]94-margaret dawson — from [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court , [he]403-an old groom believed . [I]0-i felt it rather formidable ; and first began to understand what was meant by going among [strangers]405-strangers , when [I]0-i lost sight of [the guard to whom [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother had intrusted [me]0-i]406-the guard to whom my mother had intrusted me . [I]0-i was perched up in a high gig with a hood to it , such as in those days was called a chair , and [[my]0-i companion]408-my companion was driving deliberately through [the most pastoral country [I]0-i had ever yet seen]409-the most pastoral country i had ever yet seen . [By - and - by]410-by - and - by [we]411-we ascended [a long hill]412-a long hill , and [the man]413-the man got out and walked at the horse ’s head . [I]0-i should have liked to walk , too , very much indeed ; but [I]0-i did not know how far [I]0-i might do it ; and , in fact , [I]0-i dared not speak to ask to be helped down the deep steps of the gig . [We]411-we were at last at the top,—on a long , breezy , sweeping , [unenclosed piece of ground]414-unenclosed piece of ground , called , as [I]0-i afterwards learnt , a Chase . [The groom]415-the groom stopped , breathed , patted [his]415-the groom horse , and then mounted again to [my]0-i side . “ Are [we]411-we near [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i asked . “ Near ! Why , [Miss]3044-miss ! [we]411-we ’ve a matter of ten mile yet to go . ”[415-the groom] Once launched into conversation , [we]411-we went on pretty glibly . [I]0-i fancy [he]415-the groom had been afraid of beginning to speak to [me]0-i , just as [I]0-i was to [him]415-the groom ; but [he]415-the groom got over [his]415-the groom shyness with [me]0-i sooner than [I]0-i did [mine]0-i with [him]415-the groom . [I]0-i let [him]415-the groom choose the subjects of conversation , although very often [I]0-i could not understand the points of interest in them : for instance , [he]415-the groom talked for more than a quarter of an hour of a famous race which [a certain dog - fox]416-a certain dog - fox had given [him]415-the groom , above thirty years before ; and spoke of all the covers and turns just as if [I]0-i knew them as well as [he]415-the groom did ; and all the time [I]0-i was wondering what kind of an animal a dog - fox might be . After [we]417-we left [the Chase]6-the chase , [the road]418-the road grew worse . [No one in these days , who has not seen the byroads of fifty years ago]419-no one in these days , who has not seen the byroads of fifty years ago , can imagine what they were . [We]417-we had to quarter , as [Randal]102-randal called it , nearly all the way along [the deep - rutted , miry lanes]420-the deep - rutted , miry lanes ; and the tremendous jolts [I]0-i occasionally met with made [my]0-i seat in [the gig]421-the gig so unsteady that [I]0-i could not look about [me]0-i at all , [I]0-i was so much occupied in holding on . [The road]418-the road was too muddy for [me]0-i to walk without dirtying [myself]0-i more than [I]0-i liked to do , just before [my]0-i first sight of [[my]0-i Lady]336-my lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow . But by - and - by , when [we]417-we came to [the fields in which [the lane]425-the lane ended]424-the fields in which the lane ended , [I]0-i begged [Randal]102-randal to help [me]0-i down , as [I]0-i saw that [I]0-i could pick [my]0-i steps among the pasture grass without making [myself]0-i unfit to be seen ; and [Randal]102-randal , out of pity for [his]102-randal steaming horse , wearied with the hard struggle through the mud , thanked [me]0-i kindly , and helped [me]0-i down with a springing jump . [The pastures]426-the pastures fell gradually down to [the lower land]427-the lower land , shut in on either side by rows of high elms , as if there had been a wide grand avenue here in former times . Down [the grassy gorge]428-the grassy gorge [we]417-we went , seeing the sunset sky at the end of the shadowed descent . Suddenly [we]417-we came to a long flight of steps . “ If [you]0-i ’ll run down there , [Miss]3045-miss , [I]429-i ’ll go round and meet [you]0-i , and then [you]0-i ’d better mount again , for [[my]429-i lady]336-my lady will like to see [you]0-i drive up to [the house]3047-the house . ”[429-i] “ Are [we]417-we near [the house]3047-the house ? ”[0-i] said [I]0-i , suddenly checked by the idea . “ Down there , [Miss]3049-miss , ”[429-i] replied [he]429-i , pointing with [his]429-i whip to certain stacks of twisted chimneys rising out of a group of trees , in deep shadow against the crimson light , and which lay just beyond a great square lawn at the base of the steep slope of a hundred yards , on the edge of which [we]417-we stood . [I]0-i went down the steps quietly enough . [I]0-i met [Randal]102-randal and [the gig]421-the gig at the bottom ; and , falling into [a side road to the left]431-a side road to the left , [we]417-we drove sedately round , through the gateway , and into [the great court]432-the great court in front of [the house]3047-the house . [The road by which [we]417-we had come]434-the road by which we had come lay right at the back . [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court is [a vast red - brick house]435-a vast red - brick house — at least , [it]7-hanbury court is cased in part with red bricks ; and [the gate - house and walls about [the place]437-the place]436-the gate - house and walls about the place are of brick,—with stone facings at every corner , and door , and window , such as [you]438-you see at [Hampton Court]8-hampton court . At the back are [the gables]439-the gables , and arched doorways , and stone mullions , which show ( so [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow used to tell [us]417-we ) that [it]7-hanbury court was once [a priory]440-a priory . There was [[a prior]441-a prior ’s parlour]442-a prior ’s parlour , [I]0-i know — only [we]417-we called it [[Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott ’s room]443-mrs. medlicott ’s room ; and there was [a tithe - barn]444-a tithe - barn as big as [a church]445-a church , and rows of fish - ponds , all got ready for [the monks]446-the monks ’ fasting - days in old time . But all this [I]0-i did not see till afterwards . [I]0-i hardly noticed , this first night , the great Virginian Creeper ( said to have been the first planted in [England]9-england by [one of [[my]0-i lady ’s ancestors]448-my lady ’s ancestors ) that half covered the front of [the house]3047-the house]447-one of my lady ’s ancestors ) that half covered the front of the house . As [I]0-i had been unwilling to leave the guard of [the coach]389-the coach , so did [I]0-i now feel unwilling to leave [Randal]102-randal , [a known friend of three hours]451-a known friend of three hours . But there was no help for it ; in [I]0-i must go ; past [the grand - looking old gentleman holding the door open for [me]0-i , on into [the great hall]453-the great hall on the right hand , into which the sun ’s last rays were sending in glorious red [light,—the gentleman]454-light,—the gentleman]452-the grand - looking old gentleman holding the door open for me , on into the great hall on the right hand , into which the sun ’s last rays were sending in glorious red light,—the gentleman was now walking before [me,—up]455-me,—up a step on to the dais , as [I]0-i afterwards learned that [it]456-it was [called,—then]10-called,—then again to the left , through [a series of sitting - rooms]457-a series of sitting - rooms , opening one out of another , and all of [them]457-a series of sitting - rooms looking into [a stately garden]458-a stately garden , glowing , even in the twilight , with the bloom of flowers . [We]459-we went up four steps out of [the last of [these rooms]461-these rooms]460-the last of these rooms , and then [[my]0-i guide]462-my guide lifted up a heavy silk curtain and [I]0-i was in the presence of [[my]0-i Lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]333-my lady ludlow . [She]92-lady ludlow was very small of stature , and very upright . [She]92-lady ludlow wore a great lace cap , nearly half [her]92-lady ludlow own height , [I]0-i should think , that went round [her]92-lady ludlow head ( caps which tied under the chin , and which [we]459-we called “ [mobs]3050-mobs , ”[336-my lady] came in later , and [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady held [them]465-them in great contempt , saying [people]302-people might as well come down in [their]302-people nightcaps ) . In front of [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s cap was a great bow of white satin ribbon ; and a broad band of the same ribbon was tied tight round [her]92-lady ludlow head , and served to keep the cap straight . [She]92-lady ludlow had a fine Indian muslin shawl folded over [her]92-lady ludlow shoulders and across [her]92-lady ludlow chest , and an apron of the same ; a black silk mode gown , made with short sleeves and ruffles , and with the tail thereof pulled through the pocket - hole , so as to shorten it to a useful length : beneath it [she]92-lady ludlow wore , as [I]0-i could plainly see , a quilted lavender satin petticoat . [Her]92-lady ludlow hair was snowy white , but [I]0-i hardly saw it , it was so covered with [her]92-lady ludlow cap : [her]92-lady ludlow skin , even at [her]92-lady ludlow age , was waxen in texture and tint ; [her]92-lady ludlow eyes were large and dark blue , and must have been [her]92-lady ludlow great beauty when [she]92-lady ludlow was young , for there was nothing particular , as far as [I]0-i can remember , either in mouth or nose . [She]92-lady ludlow had a great gold - headed stick by [her]92-lady ludlow chair ; but [I]0-i think it was more as a mark of state and dignity than for use ; for [she]92-lady ludlow had as light and brisk a step when [she]92-lady ludlow chose as [any girl of fifteen]468-any girl of fifteen , and , in [her]92-lady ludlow private early walk of meditation in the mornings , would go as swiftly from [garden alley]469-garden alley to [garden alley]469-garden alley as [any one of [us]472-us]471-any one of us . [She]92-lady ludlow was standing up when [I]0-i went in . [I]0-i dropped [my]0-i curtsey at the door , which [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother had always taught [me]0-i as a part of good manners , and went up instinctively to [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady . [She]92-lady ludlow did not put out [her]92-lady ludlow hand , but raised [herself]92-lady ludlow a little on tiptoe , and kissed [me]0-i on both cheeks . “ [You]0-i are cold , [[my]92-lady ludlow child]3051-my child . [You]0-i shall have a dish of tea with [me]92-lady ludlow . ”[92-lady ludlow] [She]92-lady ludlow rang a little hand - bell on the table by [her]92-lady ludlow , and [[her]92-lady ludlow waiting - maid]475-her waiting - maid came in from a small anteroom ; and , as if all had been prepared , and was awaiting [my]0-i arrival , brought with [her]92-lady ludlow a small china service with tea ready made , and a plate of delicately - cut bread and butter , every morsel of which [I]0-i could have eaten , and been none the better for it , so hungry was [I]0-i after [my]0-i long ride . [The waiting - maid]476-the waiting - maid took off [my]0-i cloak , and [I]0-i sat down , sorely alarmed at the silence , the hushed foot - falls of [the subdued maiden]477-the subdued maiden over the thick carpet , and the soft voice and clear pronunciation of [[my]0-i Lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]333-my lady ludlow . [My]0-i teaspoon fell against [my]0-i cup with a sharp noise , that seemed so out of place and season that [I]0-i blushed deeply . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady caught [my]0-i eye with [hers,—both]480-hers,—both keen and sweet were those dark - blue eyes of [[her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship ’s : — “ [Your]0-i hands are very cold , [[my]336-my lady dear]3052-my dear ; take off those gloves ”[336-my lady] ( [I]0-i wore thick serviceable doeskin , and had been too shy to take them off unbidden ) , “ and let [me]336-my lady try and warm them — the evenings are very chilly . ”[336-my lady] And [she]336-my lady held [my]0-i great red hands in hers,—soft , warm , white , ring - laden . Looking at last a little wistfully into [my]0-i face , [she]336-my lady said—“Poor [child]3053-child ! And [you]3053-child ’re [the eldest of nine !]3054-the eldest of nine ! [I]336-my lady had [a daughter who would have been just]3055-a daughter who would have been just [your]3053-child age ; but [I]336-my lady can not fancy [her]3055-a daughter who would have been just [the eldest of nine]3056-the eldest of nine . ”[336-my lady] Then came a pause of silence ; and then [she]336-my lady rang [her]336-my lady bell , and desired [[her]336-my lady waiting - maid]475-her waiting - maid , [Adams]104-adams , to show [me]0-i to [[my]0-i room]483-my room . It was so small that [I]0-i think it must have been [a cell]484-a cell . The walls were whitewashed stone ; the bed was of white dimity . There was a small piece of red staircarpet on each side of the bed , and two chairs . In a closet adjoining were [my]0-i washstand and toilet - table . There was a text of Scripture painted on the wall right opposite to [my]0-i bed ; and below hung a print , common enough in those days , of [King George]105-king george and [Queen Charlotte]106-queen charlotte , with all [[their]485-their numerous children]486-their numerous children , down to the little Princess Amelia in [a go - cart]487-a go - cart . On each side hung a small portrait , also engraved : on the left , it was [Louis]107-louis [the Sixteenth]488-the sixteenth ; on the other , [Marie - Antoinette]108-marie - antoinette . On the chimney - piece there was a tinder - box and a Prayer - book . [I]0-i do not remember anything else in [the room]489-the room . Indeed , in those days [people]302-people did not dream of writing - tables , and inkstands , and portfolios , and easy chairs , and what not . [We]491-we were taught to go into [[our]491-we bed - rooms]492-our bed - rooms for the purposes of dressing , and sleeping , and praying . Presently [I]0-i was summoned to supper . [I]0-i followed [the young lady who had been sent to call [me]0-i , down the wide shallow stairs]493-the young lady who had been sent to call me , down the wide shallow stairs , into [the great hall]453-the great hall , through which [I]0-i had first passed on [my]0-i way to [[[my]0-i Lady]336-my lady [[Ludlow]92-lady ludlow ’s room]497-ludlow ’s room]496-my lady ludlow ’s room . There were [four other young gentlewomen]498-four other young gentlewomen , all standing , and all silent , who curtsied to [me]0-i when [I]0-i first came in . [They]498-four other young gentlewomen were dressed in a kind of uniform : muslin caps bound round [their]498-four other young gentlewomen heads with blue ribbons , plain muslin handkerchiefs , lawn aprons , and drab - coloured stuff gowns . [They]498-four other young gentlewomen were all gathered together at a little distance from the table , on which were placed a couple of cold chickens , a salad , and a fruit tart . On the dais there was a smaller round table , on which stood a silver jug filled with milk , and a small roll . Near that was set a carved chair , with [a countess]499-a countess ’s coronet surmounting the back of it . [I]0-i thought that [some one]500-some one might have spoken to [me]0-i ; but [they]500-some one were shy , and [I]0-i was shy ; or else there was some other reason ; but , indeed , almost the minute after [I]0-i had come into [the hall]501-the hall by the door at the lower hand , [[her]499-a countess ladyship]3041-her ladyship entered by the door opening upon the dais ; whereupon [we]503-we all curtsied very low ; [I]0-i because [I]0-i saw [the others]504-the others do it . [She]499-a countess stood , and looked at [us]503-we for a moment . “ [Young gentlewomen]3057-young gentlewomen , ”[499-a countess] said [she]499-a countess , “ make [Margaret Dawson]94-margaret dawson welcome among [you]3057-young gentlewomen ; ”[499-a countess] and [they]500-some one treated [me]0-i with the kind politeness due to [a stranger]505-a stranger , but still without any talking beyond what was required for the purposes of the meal . After it was over , and grace was said by [one of [[our]503-we party]507-our party]506-one of our party , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady rang [her]499-a countess hand - bell , and [the servants]509-the servants came in and cleared away the supper things : then [they]509-the servants brought in a portable reading - desk , which was placed on the dais , and , [the whole household]510-the whole household trooping in , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady called to [one of [[my]0-i companions]513-my companions]512-one of my companions to come up and read the Psalms and Lessons for the day . [I]0-i remember thinking how afraid [I]0-i should have been had [I]0-i been in [[her]499-a countess place]514-her place . There were no prayers . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady thought it schismatic to have any prayers excepting those in the Prayer - book ; and would as soon have preached a sermon [herself]499-a countess in [the parish church]516-the parish church , as have allowed [any one not a deacon]517-any one not a deacon at the least to read prayers in [a private dwelling - house]518-a private dwelling - house . [I]0-i am not sure that even then [she]336-my lady would have approved of [his]519-his reading them in an unconsecrated place . [She]336-my lady had been maid - of - honour to [Queen Charlotte]106-queen charlotte : a Hanbury of that old stock that flourished in the days of [the Plantagenets]109-the plantagenets , and [heiress of all the land that remained to [the family]331-the family , of [the great estates which had once stretched into [four separate counties]523-four separate counties]522-the great estates which had once stretched into four separate counties]520-heiress of all the land that remained to the family , of the great estates which had once stretched into four separate counties . [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court was [hers]336-my lady by right . [She]336-my lady had married [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow , and had lived for many years at [[his]99-lord ludlow various seats]524-his various seats , and away from [[her]336-my lady ancestral home]525-her ancestral home . [She]336-my lady had lost all [[her]336-my lady children]526-her children but one , and most of [them]526-her children had died at [these houses of [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow ’s]527-these houses of lord ludlow ’s ; and , [I]0-i dare say , that gave [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady a distaste to [the places]529-the places , and a longing to come back to [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court , where [she]336-my lady had been so happy as [a girl]304-a girl . [I]0-i imagine [her]336-my lady girlhood had been the happiest time of [her]336-my lady life ; for , now [I]0-i think of it , most of [her]336-my lady opinions , when [I]0-i knew [her]336-my lady in later life , were singular enough then , but had been universally prevalent fifty years before . For instance , while [I]0-i lived at [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court , the cry for education was beginning to come up : [Mr. Raikes]110-mr. raikes had set up [[his]110-mr. raikes Sunday Schools]531-his sunday schools ; and [some clergymen]532-some clergymen were all for teaching writing and arithmetic , as well as reading . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady would have none of this ; it was levelling and revolutionary , [she]336-my lady said . When [a young woman]534-a young woman came to be hired , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady would have [her]534-a young woman in , and see if [she]534-a young woman liked [her]534-a young woman looks and [her]534-a young woman dress , and question [her]534-a young woman about [[her]534-a young woman family]536-her family . [[Her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship laid great stress upon this latter point , saying that [a girl who did not warm up when any interest or curiosity was expressed about [[her]538-a girl who did not warm up when any interest or curiosity was expressed about her mother , or the “ baby ” ( if there was one ) , was not likely to make a good servant mother]539-her mother , or [the “ baby ”[3041-her ladyship] ( if there was one )]540-the “ baby ” ( if there was one ) , was not likely to make [a good servant]541-a good servant]538-a girl who did not warm up when any interest or curiosity was expressed about her mother , or the “ baby ” ( if there was one ) , was not likely to make a good servant . Then [she]3041-her ladyship would make [her]534-a young woman put out [her]534-a young woman feet , to see if they were well and neatly shod . Then [she]3041-her ladyship would bid [her]534-a young woman say [the Lord]542-the lord ’s Prayer and the Creed . Then [she]3041-her ladyship inquired if [she]534-a young woman could write . If [she]534-a young woman could , and [she]534-a young woman had liked all that had gone before , [her]534-a young woman face sank — it was a great disappointment , for it was an all but inviolable rule with [her]534-a young woman never to engage [a servant who could write]543-a servant who could write . But [I]0-i have known [[her]534-a young woman ladyship]3041-her ladyship break through it , although in both cases in which [she]3041-her ladyship did so [she]3041-her ladyship put [the girl]545-the girl ’s principles to a further and unusual test in asking [her]534-a young woman to repeat the Ten Commandments . [One pert young woman]546-one pert young woman — and yet [I]0-i was sorry for [her]546-one pert young woman too , only [she]546-one pert young woman afterwards married [a rich draper in [Shrewsbury]11-shrewsbury]547-a rich draper in shrewsbury — who had got through [her]546-one pert young woman trials pretty tolerably , considering [she]546-one pert young woman could write , spoilt all , by saying glibly , at the end of the last Commandment , “ An’t please [[your]3041-her ladyship ladyship]3058-your ladyship , [I]336-my lady can cast accounts . ”[336-my lady] “ Go away , [wench]3059-wench , ”[336-my lady] said [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady in a hurry , “ [you]3059-wench ’re only fit for trade ; [you]3059-wench will not suit [me]336-my lady for [a servant]3060-a servant . ”[336-my lady] [The girl]545-the girl went away crestfallen : in a minute , however , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady sent [me]0-i after [her]545-the girl to see that [she]545-the girl had something to eat before leaving [the house]3047-the house ; and , indeed , [she]336-my lady sent for [her]545-the girl once again , but it was only to give [her]545-the girl a Bible , and to bid [her]545-the girl beware of French principles , which had led [the French]111-the french to cut off [[their]111-the french king]552-their king ’s and [queen]553-queen ’s heads . [The poor , blubbering girl]554-the poor , blubbering girl said , “ Indeed , [[my]554-the poor , blubbering girl lady]336-my lady , [I]554-the poor , blubbering girl would n’t hurt a fly , much less [a king]3062-a king , and [I]554-the poor , blubbering girl can not abide the French , nor frogs neither , for that matter . ”[554-the poor , blubbering girl] But [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady was inexorable , and took [a girl who could neither read nor write]556-a girl who could neither read nor write , to make up for [her]336-my lady alarm about the progress of education towards addition and subtraction ; and afterwards , when [the clergyman who was at [Hanbury parish]558-hanbury parish when [I]0-i came [there]559-there]557-the clergyman who was at hanbury parish when i came there , had died , and [the bishop]560-the bishop had appointed another , and [a younger man]561-a younger man , in [his]560-the bishop stead , this was one of the points on which [he]560-the bishop and [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady did not agree . While [good old deaf Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford lived , it was [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s custom , when indisposed for a sermon , to stand up at the door of [her]336-my lady large square pew,—just opposite to the reading - desk,—and to say ( at that part of the morning service where it is decreed that , in quires and places where [they]564-they sing , here followeth the anthem ): “ [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford , [I]113-mr. gray will not trouble [you]112-mr. mountford for a discourse this morning . ”[113-mr. gray] And [we]565-we all knelt down to the Litany with great satisfaction ; for [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford , though [he]112-mr. mountford could not hear , had always [his]112-mr. mountford eyes open about this part of the service , for any of [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s movements . But [the new clergyman]567-the new clergyman , [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , was of a different stamp . [He]113-mr. gray was very zealous in all [his]113-mr. gray parish work ; and [[my]0-i lady , who was just as good as [she]336-my lady could be to [the poor]569-the poor]568-my lady , who was just as good as she could be to the poor , was often crying [him]113-mr. gray up as [a godsend to [the parish]571-the parish]570-a godsend to the parish , and [he]113-mr. gray never could send amiss to [the Court]572-the court when [he]113-mr. gray wanted broth , or wine , or jelly , or sago for [a sick person]573-a sick person . But [he]113-mr. gray needs must take up the new hobby of education ; and [I]0-i could see that this put [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady sadly about one Sunday , when [she]336-my lady suspected , [I]0-i know not how , that there was something to be said in [his]113-mr. gray sermon about [a Sunday - school which [he]113-mr. gray was planning]575-a sunday - school which he was planning . [She]336-my lady stood up , as [she]336-my lady had not done since [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford ’s death , two years and better before this time , and said — “ [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , [I]336-my lady will not trouble [you]113-mr. gray for a discourse this morning . ”[336-my lady] But [her]336-my lady voice was not well - assured and steady ; and [we]576-we knelt down with more of curiosity than satisfaction in [our]576-we minds . [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray preached a very rousing sermon , on the necessity of establishing [a Sabbath - school in [the village]578-the village]577-a sabbath - school in the village . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady shut [her]336-my lady eyes , and seemed to go to sleep ; but [I]0-i do n’t believe [she]336-my lady lost a word of it , though [she]336-my lady said nothing about it that [I]0-i heard until the next Saturday , when two of [us]576-we , as was the custom , were riding out with [her]336-my lady in [[her]336-my lady carriage]580-her carriage , and [we]576-we went to see [a poor bedridden woman , who lived some miles away at the other end of [the estate]582-the estate and of [the parish]571-the parish]581-a poor bedridden woman , who lived some miles away at the other end of the estate and of the parish : and as [we]576-we came out of [the cottage]584-the cottage [we]576-we met [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray walking up to [it]584-the cottage , in a great heat , and looking very tired . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady beckoned [him]113-mr. gray to [her]336-my lady , and told [him]113-mr. gray [she]336-my lady should wait and take [him]113-mr. gray [home]586-home with [her]336-my lady , adding that [she]336-my lady wondered to see [him]113-mr. gray there , so far from [[his]113-mr. gray home]587-his home , for that it was beyond a Sabbath - day ’s journey , and , from what [she]336-my lady had gathered from [his]113-mr. gray sermon the last Sunday , [he]113-mr. gray was all for Judaism against Christianity . [He]113-mr. gray looked as if [he]113-mr. gray did not understand what [she]336-my lady meant ; but the truth was that , besides the way in which [he]113-mr. gray had spoken up for [schools]588-schools and schooling , [he]113-mr. gray had kept calling Sunday the Sabbath : and , as [[her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship said , “ The Sabbath is the Sabbath , and that ’s one thing — it is Saturday ; and if [I]113-mr. gray keep it , [I]113-mr. gray ’m [a Jew]3063-a jew , which [I]113-mr. gray ’m not . And Sunday is Sunday ; and that ’s another thing ; and if [I]113-mr. gray keep it , [I]113-mr. gray ’m [a Christian]3064-a christian , which [I]113-mr. gray humbly trust [I]113-mr. gray am . ”[113-mr. gray] But when [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray got an inkling of [her]336-my lady meaning in talking about a Sabbath - day ’s journey , [he]113-mr. gray only took notice of a part of it : [he]113-mr. gray smiled and bowed , and said [no one]590-no one knew better than [[her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship what were the duties that abrogated all inferior laws regarding the Sabbath ; and that [he]113-mr. gray must go in and read to [old Betty Brown]114-old betty brown , so that [he]113-mr. gray would not detain [[her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship . “ But [I]336-my lady shall wait for [you]113-mr. gray , [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , ”[336-my lady] said [she]336-my lady . “ Or [I]336-my lady will take a drive round by [Oakfield]12-oakfield , and be back in an hour ’s time . ”[336-my lady] For , [you]593-you see , [she]336-my lady would not have [him]113-mr. gray feel hurried or troubled with a thought that [he]113-mr. gray was keeping [her]336-my lady waiting , while [he]113-mr. gray ought to be comforting and praying with [old Betty]114-old betty brown . “ [A very pretty young man]3065-a very pretty young man , [[my]336-my lady dears]3066-my dears , ”[336-my lady] said [she]336-my lady , as [we]594-we drove away . “ But [I]336-my lady shall have [[my]336-my lady pew]3067-my pew glazed all the same . ”[336-my lady] [We]594-we did not know what [she]336-my lady meant at the time ; but the next Sunday but one [we]594-we did . [She]336-my lady had the curtains all round [the grand old Hanbury family seat]595-the grand old hanbury family seat taken down , and , instead of them , there was glass up to the height of six or seven feet . [We]594-we entered by a door , with a window in it that drew up or down just like what [you]596-you see in [carriages]597-carriages . This window was generally down , and then [we]594-we could hear perfectly ; but if [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray used the word “ Sabbath , ”[113-mr. gray] or spoke in favour of schooling and education , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady stepped out of [her]336-my lady corner , and drew up the window with a decided clang and clash . [I]0-i must tell [you]596-you something more about [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . The presentation to [the living of [Hanbury]13-hanbury]599-the living of hanbury was vested in [two trustees]600-two trustees , of whom [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow was one : [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow had exercised this right in the appointment of [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford , who had won [[his]99-lord ludlow lordship]601-his lordship ’s favour by [his]112-mr. mountford excellent horsemanship . Nor was [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford [a bad clergyman]602-a bad clergyman , as [clergymen]603-clergymen went in those days . [He]112-mr. mountford did not drink , though [he]112-mr. mountford liked good eating as much as any one . And if [any poor person]604-any poor person was ill , and [he]112-mr. mountford heard of it , [he]112-mr. mountford would send [them]604-any poor person plates from [his]112-mr. mountford own dinner of what [he]112-mr. mountford [himself]112-mr. mountford liked best ; sometimes of dishes which were almost as bad as poison to [sick people]605-sick people . [He]112-mr. mountford meant kindly to everybody except [dissenters]606-dissenters , whom [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow and [he]112-mr. mountford united in trying to drive out of [the parish]571-the parish ; and among [dissenters]606-dissenters [he]112-mr. mountford particularly abhorred [Methodists]609-methodists — [some one]500-some one said , because [John Wesley]115-john wesley had objected to [his]112-mr. mountford hunting . But that must have been long ago for when [I]0-i knew [him]112-mr. mountford [he]112-mr. mountford was far too stout and too heavy to hunt ; besides , [the bishop of [the diocese]612-the diocese]611-the bishop of the diocese disapproved of hunting , and had intimated [his]611-the bishop of the diocese disapprobation to [the clergy]613-the clergy . For [my]0-i own part , [I]0-i think a good run would not have come amiss , even in a moral point of view , to [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford . [He]112-mr. mountford ate so much , and took so little exercise , that [[we]614-we [young women]616-young women]615-we young women often heard of [his]112-mr. mountford being in terrible passions with [[his]112-mr. mountford servants]617-his servants , and [the sexton and clerk]618-the sexton and clerk . But [they]616-young women [none of [them]616-young women]619-none of them minded [him]112-mr. mountford much , for [he]112-mr. mountford soon came to [himself]112-mr. mountford , and was sure to make [them]616-young women some present or other — some said in proportion to [his]112-mr. mountford anger ; so that [the sexton , who was a bit of a wag ( as all sextons]620-the sexton , who was a bit of a wag ( as all sextons are , [I]0-i think ) , said that [the vicar]621-the vicar ’s saying , “ [The Devil]3068-the devil take [you]3069-you , ”[621-the vicar] was worth a shilling any day , whereas “ [The Deuce]116-the deuce ”[621-the vicar] was a shabby sixpenny speech , only fit for [a curate]622-a curate . There was a great deal of good in [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford , too . [He]112-mr. mountford could not bear to see pain , or sorrow , or misery of any kind ; and , if it came under [his]112-mr. mountford notice , [he]112-mr. mountford was never easy till [he]112-mr. mountford had relieved it , for the time , at any rate . But [he]112-mr. mountford was afraid of being made uncomfortable ; so , if [he]112-mr. mountford possibly could , [he]112-mr. mountford would avoid seeing [any one who was ill or unhappy]623-any one who was ill or unhappy ; and [he]112-mr. mountford did not thank [any one]624-any one for telling [him]112-mr. mountford about [them]623-any one who was ill or unhappy . “ What would [[your]92-lady ludlow ladyship]3058-your ladyship have [me]112-mr. mountford to do ? ”[112-mr. mountford] [he]112-mr. mountford once said to [[my]0-i Lady [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow]92-lady ludlow , when [she]92-lady ludlow wished [him]112-mr. mountford to go and see [a poor man who had broken [his]625-a poor man who had broken his leg leg]625-a poor man who had broken his leg . “ [I]92-lady ludlow can not piece the leg as [the doctor]3071-the doctor can ; [I]92-lady ludlow can not nurse [him]625-a poor man who had broken his leg as well as [[his]625-a poor man who had broken his leg wife]3072-his wife does ; [I]92-lady ludlow may talk to [him]625-a poor man who had broken his leg , but [he]625-a poor man who had broken his leg no more understands [me]92-lady ludlow than [I]92-lady ludlow do the language of [the alchemists]3073-the alchemists . [My]92-lady ludlow coming puts [him]625-a poor man who had broken his leg out ; [he]625-a poor man who had broken his leg stiffens [himself]625-a poor man who had broken his leg into an uncomfortable posture , out of respect to the cloth , and dare not take the comfort of kicking , and swearing , and scolding [[his]625-a poor man who had broken his leg wife]3072-his wife , while [I]92-lady ludlow am there . [I]92-lady ludlow hear [him]625-a poor man who had broken his leg , with [my]92-lady ludlow figurative ears , [[my]92-lady ludlow lady]336-my lady , heave a sigh of relief when [my]92-lady ludlow back is turned , and the sermon that [he]625-a poor man who had broken his leg thinks [I]92-lady ludlow ought to have kept for the pulpit , and have delivered to [[his]625-a poor man who had broken his leg neighbours]3076-his neighbours ( whose case , as [he]625-a poor man who had broken his leg fancies , it would just have fitted , as it seemed to [him]625-a poor man who had broken his leg to be addressed to [the sinful]3077-the sinful ) , is all ended , and done , for the day . [I]92-lady ludlow judge [others]3078-others as [myself]92-lady ludlow ; [I]92-lady ludlow do to [them]3078-others as [I]92-lady ludlow would be done to . [That ’s Christianity]3079-that ’s christianity , at any rate . [I]92-lady ludlow should hate — saving [[your]625-a poor man who had broken his leg ladyship]3058-your ladyship ’s presence — to have [[my]92-lady ludlow Lord]3081-my lord [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow coming and seeing [me]92-lady ludlow , if [I]92-lady ludlow were ill . ’ Twould be a great honour , no doubt ; but [I]92-lady ludlow should have to put on a clean nightcap for the occasion ; and sham patience , in order to be polite , and not weary [[his]3081-my lord lordship]601-his lordship with [my]92-lady ludlow complaints . [I]92-lady ludlow should be twice as thankful to [him]3081-my lord if [he]3081-my lord would send [me]92-lady ludlow game , or [a good fat haunch]3083-a good fat haunch , to bring [me]92-lady ludlow up to that pitch of health and strength one ought to be in , to appreciate the honour of a visit from [a nobleman]3084-a nobleman . So [I]92-lady ludlow shall send [Jerry Butler]117-jerry butler a good dinner every day till [he]117-jerry butler is strong again ; and spare [the poor old fellow]3085-the poor old fellow [my]92-lady ludlow presence and advice . ”[92-lady ludlow] [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady would be puzzled by this , and by many other of [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford ’s speeches . But [he]112-mr. mountford had been appointed by [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord , and [she]336-my lady could not question [[her]336-my lady dead husband]628-her dead husband ’s wisdom ; and [she]336-my lady knew that the dinners were always sent , and often a guinea or two to help to pay [the doctor]3071-the doctor ’s bills ; and [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford was true blue , as [we]630-we call it , to the back - bone ; hated [the dissenters]631-the dissenters and [the French]632-the french ; and could hardly drink a dish of tea without giving out the toast of “ Church and [King]3086-king , and down with the Rump . ”[112-mr. mountford] Moreover , [he]112-mr. mountford had once had the honour of preaching before [the King]633-the king and [Queen]553-queen , and two of [the Princesses]635-the princesses , at [Weymouth]14-weymouth ; and [the King]633-the king had applauded [his]633-the king sermon audibly with,—“Very good ; very good ; ”[633-the king] and that was a seal put upon [his]112-mr. mountford merit in [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s eyes . Besides , in the long winter Sunday evenings , [he]112-mr. mountford would come up to [the Court]572-the court , and read a sermon to [[us]630-we girls]639-us girls , and play a game of picquet with [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady afterwards ; which served to shorten the tedium of the time . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady would , on those occasions , invite [him]112-mr. mountford to sup with [her]336-my lady on the dais ; but as [her]336-my lady meal was invariably bread and milk only , [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford preferred sitting down amongst [us]630-we , and made a joke about its being wicked and heterodox to eat meagre on Sunday , a festival of [the Church]642-the church . [We]630-we smiled at this joke just as much the twentieth time [we]630-we heard it as [we]630-we did at the first ; for [we]630-we knew it was coming , because [he]112-mr. mountford always coughed a little nervously before [he]112-mr. mountford made a joke , for fear [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady should not approve : and neither [she]336-my lady nor [he]112-mr. mountford seemed to remember that [he]112-mr. mountford had ever hit upon the idea before . [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford died quite suddenly at last . [We]630-we were all very sorry to lose [him]112-mr. mountford . [He]112-mr. mountford left some of [[his]112-mr. mountford property]644-his property ( for [he]112-mr. mountford had [a private estate]645-a private estate ) to [the poor of [the parish]571-the parish]646-the poor of the parish , to furnish [them]646-the poor of the parish with an annual Christmas dinner of roast beef and plum pudding , for which [he]112-mr. mountford wrote out a very good receipt in the codicil to [his]112-mr. mountford will . Moreover , [he]112-mr. mountford desired [[his]112-mr. mountford executors]648-his executors to see that [the vault , in which [the vicars of]650-the vicars of [Hanbury]13-hanbury were interred]649-the vault , in which the vicars of hanbury were interred , was well aired , before [his]112-mr. mountford coffin was taken in ; for , all [his]112-mr. mountford life long , [he]112-mr. mountford had had a dread of damp , and latterly [he]112-mr. mountford kept [[his]112-mr. mountford rooms]651-his rooms to such a pitch of warmth that some thought it hastened [his]112-mr. mountford end . Then [the other trustee]652-the other trustee , as [I]0-i have said , presented the living to [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , Fellow of [Lincoln College]15-lincoln college , [Oxford]16-oxford . It was quite natural for [us]653-us all , as belonging in some sort to [the Hanbury family]654-the hanbury family , to disapprove of [the other trustee]652-the other trustee ’s choice . But when [some ill - natured person]656-some ill - natured person circulated the report that [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray was [a Moravian Methodist]657-a moravian methodist , [I]0-i remember [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady said , “ [She]336-my lady could not believe anything so bad , without a great deal of evidence . ”[336-my lady] CHAPTER II . Before [I]0-i tell [you]659-you about [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , [I]0-i think [I]0-i ought to make [you]659-you understand something more of what [we]653-us did all day long at [Hanbury Court]7-hanbury court . There were five of [us]653-us at the time of which [I]0-i am speaking , [all young women of good descent]660-all young women of good descent , and allied ( however distantly ) to [people of rank]661-people of rank . When [we]653-us were not with [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady , [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott looked after [us]653-us ; [a gentle little woman , who had been companion to [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady for many years , and was indeed , [I]0-i have been told , some kind of relation to [her]336-my lady]663-a gentle little woman , who had been companion to my lady for many years , and was indeed , i have been told , some kind of relation to her . [[Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott ’s parents]665-mrs. medlicott ’s parents had lived in [Germany]17-germany , and the consequence was , [she]103-mrs. medlicott spoke English with a very foreign accent . Another consequence was , that [she]103-mrs. medlicott excelled in all manner of needlework , such as is not known even by name in these days . [She]103-mrs. medlicott could darn either lace , table - linen , India muslin , or stockings , so that [no one]590-no one could tell where the hole or rent had been . Though [a good Protestant]667-a good protestant , and never missing [Guy Faux]118-guy faux day at [church]668-church , [she]103-mrs. medlicott was as skilful at fine work as [any nun in [a Papist convent]670-a papist convent]669-any nun in a papist convent . [She]103-mrs. medlicott would take a piece of French cambric , and by drawing out some threads , and working in others , it became delicate lace in a very few hours . [She]103-mrs. medlicott did the same by Hollands cloth , and made coarse strong lace , with which all [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s napkins and table - linen were trimmed . [We]672-we worked under [her]103-mrs. medlicott during a great part of the day , either in [the still - room]673-the still - room , or at [our]672-we sewing in [a chamber that opened out of [the great hall]453-the great hall]674-a chamber that opened out of the great hall . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady despised every kind of work that would now be called Fancy - work . [She]336-my lady considered that the use of coloured threads or worsted was only fit to amuse [children]324-children ; but that [grown women]678-grown women ought not to be taken with mere blues and reds , but to restrict [their]678-grown women pleasure in sewing to making small and delicate stitches . [She]336-my lady would speak of the old tapestry in [the hall]501-the hall as the work of [[her]336-my lady ancestresses]680-her ancestresses , who lived before the Reformation , and were consequently unacquainted with pure and simple tastes in work , as well as in religion . Nor would [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady sanction the fashion of the day , which , at the beginning of this century , made [all the fine ladies]682-all the fine ladies take to making shoes . [She]336-my lady said that such work was a consequence of the French Revolution , which had done much to annihilate all distinctions of rank and class , and hence it was , that [she]336-my lady saw [young ladies of birth and breeding handling lasts , and awls , and dirty cobblers’-wax]683-young ladies of birth and breeding handling lasts , and awls , and dirty cobblers’-wax , like [[shoe - makers]684-shoe - makers ’ daughters]685-shoe - makers ’ daughters . Very frequently [one of [us]687-we]686-one of us would be summoned to [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady to read aloud to [her]336-my lady , as [she]336-my lady sat in [[her]336-my lady small withdrawing - room]689-her small withdrawing - room , some improving book . It was generally [[Mr. Addison]119-mr. addison ’s “ Spectator]3087-mr. addison ’s “ spectator ; ”[119-mr. addison] but one year , [I]0-i remember , [we]687-we had to read “ [Sturm]120-sturm ’s Reflections ”[119-mr. addison] translated from a German book [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott recommended . [Mr. Sturm]120-sturm told [us]687-we what to think about for every day in the year ; and very dull it was ; but [I]0-i believe [Queen Charlotte]106-queen charlotte had liked the book very much , and the thought of [her]106-queen charlotte royal approbation kept [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady awake during the reading . “ [Mrs. Chapone]121-mrs. chapone ’s Letters ”[106-queen charlotte] and “ [Dr. Gregory]122-dr. gregory ’s Advice to [Young Ladies]3088-young ladies ”[106-queen charlotte] composed the rest of [[our]687-we library]691-our library for week - day reading . [I]0-i , for one , was glad to leave [my]0-i fine sewing , and even [my]0-i reading aloud ( though this last did keep [me]0-i with [[my]0-i dear lady]692-my dear lady ) to go to [the still - room]673-the still - room and potter about among the preserves and the medicated waters . There was [no doctor]694-no doctor for many miles round , and with [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott to direct [us]687-we , and [Dr. Buchan]123-dr. buchan to go by for recipes , [we]687-we sent out many a bottle of physic , which , [I]0-i dare say , was as good as what comes out of [[the druggist]695-the druggist ’s shop]696-the druggist ’s shop . At any rate , [I]0-i do not think [we]687-we did much harm ; for if any of [our]687-we physics tasted stronger than usual , [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott would bid [us]687-we let it down with cochineal and water , to make all safe , as [she]103-mrs. medlicott said . So [our]687-we bottles of medicine had very little real physic in them at last ; but [we]687-we were careful in putting labels on them , which looked very mysterious to [those who could not read]697-those who could not read , and helped the medicine to do its work . [I]0-i have sent off many a bottle of salt and water coloured red ; and whenever [we]687-we had nothing else to do in [the still - room]673-the still - room , [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott would set [us]687-we to making bread - pills , by way of practice ; and , as far as [I]0-i can say , they were very efficacious , as before [we]687-we gave out a box [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott always told [the patient]699-the patient what symptoms to expect ; and [I]0-i hardly ever inquired without hearing that [they]700-they had produced [their]700-they effect . There was [one old man , who took six pills a - night]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night , of any kind [we]687-we liked to give [him]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night , to make [him]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night sleep ; and if , by any chance , [[his]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night daughter]702-his daughter had forgotten to let [us]687-we know that [he]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night was out of [his]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night medicine , [he]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night was so restless and miserable that , as [he]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night said , [he]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night thought [he]701-one old man , who took six pills a - night was like to die . [I]0-i think [ours]687-we was what would be called homoeopathic practice now - a - days . Then [we]687-we learnt to make all the cakes and dishes of the season in [the still - room]673-the still - room . [We]687-we had plum - porridge and mince - pies at Christmas , fritters and pancakes on Shrove Tuesday , furmenty on Mothering Sunday , violet - cakes in Passion Week , tansy - pudding on Easter Sunday , three - cornered cakes on Trinity Sunday , and so on through the year : all made from good old Church receipts , handed down from [one of [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s earliest Protestant ancestresses]704-one of my lady ’s earliest protestant ancestresses . [Every one of [us]687-we]706-every one of us passed a portion of the day with [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow ; and now and then [we]687-we rode out with [her]92-lady ludlow in [[her]92-lady ludlow coach]707-her coach and four . [She]92-lady ludlow did not like to go out with a pair of horses , considering this rather beneath [her]92-lady ludlow rank ; and , indeed , four horses were very often needed to pull [[her]92-lady ludlow heavy coach]708-her heavy coach through the stiff mud . But it was rather a cumbersome equipage through [the narrow Warwickshire lanes]709-the narrow warwickshire lanes ; and [I]0-i used often to think it was well that [countesses]710-countesses were not plentiful , or else [we]687-we might have met [another lady of quality]711-another lady of quality in [another coach]712-another coach and four , where there would have been no possibility of turning , or passing each other , and very little chance of backing . Once when the idea of this danger of meeting [another countess]713-another countess in [a narrow , deep - rutted lane]714-a narrow , deep - rutted lane was very prominent in [my]0-i mind [I]0-i ventured to ask [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott what would have to be done on such an occasion ; and [she]103-mrs. medlicott told [me]0-i that “ de latest creation must back , for sure , ”[103-mrs. medlicott] which puzzled [me]0-i a good deal at the time , although [I]0-i understand it now . [I]0-i began to find out the use of the “ Peerage , ”[103-mrs. medlicott] a book which had seemed to [me]0-i rather dull before ; but , as [I]0-i was always a coward in [a coach]715-a coach , [I]0-i made [myself]0-i well acquainted with the dates of creation of [[our]687-we three Warwickshire earls]716-our three warwickshire earls , and was happy to find that [Earl Ludlow]124-earl ludlow ranked second , [the oldest earl]717-the oldest earl being [a hunting widower]718-a hunting widower , and not likely to drive out in [a carriage]719-a carriage . All this time [I]0-i have wandered from [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . Of course , [we]687-we first saw [him]113-mr. gray in [church]668-church when [he]113-mr. gray read [himself]113-mr. gray in . [He]113-mr. gray was very red - faced , the kind of redness which goes with light hair and a blushing complexion ; [he]113-mr. gray looked slight and short , and [his]113-mr. gray bright light frizzy hair had hardly a dash of powder in it . [I]0-i remember [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady making this observation , and sighing over it ; for , though since the famine in seventeen hundred and ninety - nine and eighteen hundred there had been a tax on hair - powder , yet it was reckoned very revolutionary and [Jacobin]125-jacobin not to wear a good deal of it . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady hardly liked the opinions of [any man who wore [his]723-any man who wore his own hair own hair]723-any man who wore his own hair ; but this [she]336-my lady would say was rather a prejudice : only in [her]336-my lady youth none but [the mob]724-the mob had gone wigless , and [she]336-my lady could not get over the association of wigs with birth and breeding ; [a man]725-a man ’s own hair with that class of people who had formed [the rioters]726-the rioters in seventeen hundred and eighty , when [Lord George Gordon]126-george had been [one of the bugbears of [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s life]727-one of the bugbears of my lady ’s life . [[Her]336-my lady husband]729-her husband and [[his]729-her husband brothers]730-his brothers , [she]336-my lady told [us]731-us , had been put into breeches , and had [their]730-his brothers heads shaved on [their]730-his brothers seventh birthday , each of [them]730-his brothers ; a handsome little wig of the newest fashion forming [the old Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow ’s invariable birthday present to [[her]336-my lady sons]732-her sons as [they]730-his brothers each arrived at that age ; and afterwards , to the day of [their]730-his brothers death , [they]730-his brothers never saw [their]730-his brothers own hair . To be without powder , as [some underbred people]733-some underbred people were talking of being now , was in fact to insult the proprieties of life , by being undressed . It was English sans - culottism . But [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray did wear a little powder , enough to save [him]113-mr. gray in [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s good opinion ; but not enough to make [her]336-my lady approve of [him]113-mr. gray decidedly . The next time [I]0-i saw [him]113-mr. gray was in [the great hall]453-the great hall . [Mary Mason]127-mary mason and [I]0-i were going to drive out with [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady in [[her]336-my lady coach]707-her coach , and when [we]738-we went down stairs with [our]738-we best hats and cloaks on , [we]738-we found [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray awaiting [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s coming . [I]0-i believe [he]113-mr. gray had paid [his]113-mr. gray respects to [her]336-my lady before , but [we]738-we had never seen [him]113-mr. gray ; and [he]113-mr. gray had declined [her]336-my lady invitation to spend Sunday evening at [the Court]572-the court ( as [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford used to do pretty regularly — and play a game at picquet too — ) , which , [Mrs. Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott told [us]738-we , had caused [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady to be not over well pleased with [him]113-mr. gray . [He]113-mr. gray blushed redder than ever at the sight of [us]738-we , as [we]738-we entered [the hall]501-the hall and dropped [him]113-mr. gray [our]738-we curtsies . [He]113-mr. gray coughed two or three times , as if [he]113-mr. gray would have liked to speak to [us]738-we , if [he]113-mr. gray could but have found something to say ; and every time [he]113-mr. gray coughed [he]113-mr. gray became hotter - looking than ever . [I]0-i am ashamed to say , [we]738-we were nearly laughing at [him]113-mr. gray ; half because [we]738-we , too , were so shy that [we]738-we understood what [his]113-mr. gray awkwardness meant . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady came in , with [her]336-my lady quick active step — [she]336-my lady always walked quickly when [she]336-my lady did not bethink [herself]336-my lady of [her]336-my lady cane — as if [she]336-my lady was sorry to have [us]738-we kept waiting — and , as [she]336-my lady entered , [she]336-my lady gave [us]738-we all round one of those graceful sweeping curtsies , of which [I]0-i think the art must have died out with [her,—it]744-her,—it implied so much courtesy;—this time it said , as well as words could do , “ [I]336-my lady am sorry to have kept [you]738-we all waiting,—forgive [me]336-my lady . ”[336-my lady] [She]336-my lady went up to the mantelpiece , near which [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray had been standing until [her]336-my lady entrance , and curtseying afresh to [him]113-mr. gray , and pretty deeply this time , because of [his]113-mr. gray cloth , and [her]336-my lady being [hostess]745-hostess , and [he]113-mr. gray , [a new guest]746-a new guest . [She]336-my lady asked [him]113-mr. gray if [he]113-mr. gray would not prefer speaking to [her]336-my lady in [[her]336-my lady own private parlour]747-her own private parlour , and looked as though [she]336-my lady would have conducted [him]113-mr. gray [there]559-there . But [he]113-mr. gray burst out with [his]113-mr. gray errand , of which [he]113-mr. gray was full even to choking , and which sent the glistening tears into [his]113-mr. gray large blue eyes , which stood farther and farther out with [his]113-mr. gray excitement . “ [[My]749-my lady,—as mr. gray lady]336-my lady , [I]749-my lady,—as mr. gray want to speak to [you]336-my lady , and to persuade [you]336-my lady to exert [your]336-my lady kind interest with [Mr. Lathom]128-mr. lathom — [Justice Lathom]129-justice lathom , of [Hathaway Manor]18-hathaway manor — ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] “ [Harry Lathom]128-mr. lathom ? ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] inquired [[my]0-i lady,—as [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray]749-my lady,—as mr. gray stopped to take the breath [he]113-mr. gray had lost in [his]113-mr. gray hurry,—“I did not know [he]113-mr. gray was in the commission . ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] “ [He]113-mr. gray is only just appointed ; [he]113-mr. gray took the oaths not a month ago,—more ’s the pity ! ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] “ [I]749-my lady,—as mr. gray do not understand why [you]336-my lady should regret it . [The Lathoms]130-the lathoms have held [Hathaway]19-hathaway since [Edward]131-edward the First , and [Mr. Lathom]128-mr. lathom bears a good character , although [his]128-mr. lathom temper is hasty — ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] “ [[My]749-my lady,—as mr. gray lady]336-my lady ! [he]128-mr. lathom has committed [Job Gregson]132-job gregson for stealing — a fault of which [he]128-mr. lathom is as innocent as [I]749-my lady,—as mr. gray — and all the evidence goes to prove it , now that the case is brought before [the Bench]3091-the bench ; only [the Squires]3092-the squires hang so together that [they]3092-the squires ca n’t be brought to see justice , and are all for sending [Job]132-job gregson to [gaol]3093-gaol , out of compliment to [Mr. Lathom]128-mr. lathom , saying it [his]128-mr. lathom first committal , and it wo n’t be civil to tell [him]128-mr. lathom there is no evidence against [[his]128-mr. lathom man]3094-his man . For [God]133-god ’s sake , [[my]749-my lady,—as mr. gray lady]336-my lady , speak to [the gentlemen]3096-the gentlemen ; [they]3096-the gentlemen will attend to [you]336-my lady , while [they]3096-the gentlemen only tell [me]749-my lady,—as mr. gray to mind [my]749-my lady,—as mr. gray own business . ”[749-my lady,—as mr. gray] Now [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady was always inclined to stand by [her]336-my lady order , and [the Lathoms of [Hathaway Court]20-hathaway court]751-the lathoms of hathaway court were [cousins to [the Hanbury]93-ursula hanbury ’s]752-cousins to the hanbury ’s . Besides , it was rather a point of honour in those days to encourage [a young magistrate]753-a young magistrate , by passing a pretty sharp sentence on [his]753-a young magistrate first committals ; and [Job Gregson]132-job gregson was [the father of [a girl who had been lately turned away from [her]755-a girl who had been lately turned away from her place as scullery - maid place as [scullery - maid]756-scullery - maid]755-a girl who had been lately turned away from her place as scullery - maid for sauciness to [Mrs. Adams]104-adams , [[her]336-my lady ladyship ’s own maid]757-her ladyship ’s own maid]754-the father of a girl who had been lately turned away from her place as scullery - maid for sauciness to mrs. adams , her ladyship ’s own maid ; and [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray had not said a word of the reasons why [he]113-mr. gray believed [the man]413-the man innocent,—for [he]113-mr. gray was in such a hurry , [I]0-i believe [he]113-mr. gray would have had [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady drive off to [the Henley Court - house]760-the henley court - house then and there;—so there seemed a good deal against [the man]413-the man , and nothing but [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray ’s bare word for [him]413-the man ; and [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady drew [herself]336-my lady a little up , and said — “ [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray ! [I]336-my lady do not see what reason either [you]113-mr. gray or [I]336-my lady have to interfere . [Mr. Harry Lathom]128-mr. lathom is [a sensible kind of young man]3097-a sensible kind of young man , well capable of ascertaining the truth without [our]3098-our help — ”[336-my lady] “ But more evidence has come out since , ”[113-mr. gray] broke in [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . [[My]0-i lady]336-my lady went a little stiffer , and spoke a little more coldly : — “ [I]336-my lady suppose this additional evidence is before [the justices]3099-the justices : [men of good family , and of honour and credit]3100-men of good family , and of honour and credit , well known in [the county]3101-the county . [They]3099-the justices naturally feel that the opinion of one of [themselves]3099-the justices must have more weight than the words of [a man like [Job Gregson]132-job gregson]3102-a man like job gregson , who bears a very indifferent character,—has been strongly suspected of poaching , coming from [no one]590-no one knows where , squatting on [[Hareman]3104-hareman ’s Common]3105-hareman ’s common — which , by the way , is extra - parochial , [I]336-my lady believe ; consequently [you]3106-you , as [a clergyman]3107-a clergyman , are not responsible for what goes on there ; and , although impolitic , there might be some truth in what [the magistrates]3108-the magistrates said , in advising [you]3106-you to mind [your]3106-you own business,”—said[336-my lady] [[her]336-my lady ladyship]3041-her ladyship , smiling,—“and [they]3108-the magistrates might be tempted to bid [me]765-he mind [mine]765-he , if [I]765-he interfered , [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray : might [they]3108-the magistrates not ? ”[765-he] [He]765-he looked extremely uncomfortable ; half angry . Once or twice [he]765-he began to speak , but checked [himself]765-he , as if [his]765-he words would not have been wise or prudent . At last [he]765-he said—“It may seem presumptuous in [[me,—a]92-lady ludlow stranger of only a few weeks ’ standing]3109-me,—a stranger of only a few weeks ’ standing — to set up [my]765-he judgment as to [men]3110-men ’s character against that of [residents]3111-residents — ”[765-he] [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow gave a little bow of acquiescence , which was , [I]0-i think , involuntary on [her]92-lady ludlow part , and which [I]0-i do n’t think [he]765-he perceived,—“but [I]92-lady ludlow am convinced that [the man]413-the man is innocent of this offence,—and besides , [the justices]3099-the justices [themselves]3099-the justices allege this ridiculous custom of paying a compliment to [a newly - appointed magistrate]3114-a newly - appointed magistrate as [their]3099-the justices only reason . ”[92-lady ludlow] That unlucky word “ ridiculous ! ”[765-he] It undid all the good [his]765-he modest beginning had done [him]765-he with [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady . [I]0-i knew as well as words could have told [me]0-i , that [she]92-lady ludlow was affronted at the expression being used by [a man inferior in rank to those whose actions [he]765-he applied it to,—and]767-a man inferior in rank to those whose actions he applied it to,—and truly , it was a great want of tact , considering to whom [he]765-he was speaking . [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow spoke very gently and slowly ; [she]92-lady ludlow always did so when [she]92-lady ludlow was annoyed ; it was a certain sign , the meaning of which [we]768-we had all learnt . “ [I]92-lady ludlow think , [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , [we]768-we will drop the subject . It is one on which [we]768-we are not likely to agree . ”[92-lady ludlow] [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray ’s ruddy colour grew purple and then faded away , and [his]113-mr. gray face became pale . [I]0-i think both [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady and [he]113-mr. gray had forgotten [our]768-we presence ; and [we]768-we were beginning to feel too awkward to wish to remind [them]770-them of it . And yet [we]768-we could not help watching and listening with the greatest interest . [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray drew [himself]113-mr. gray up to [his]113-mr. gray full height , with an unconscious feeling of dignity . Little as was [his]113-mr. gray stature , and awkward and embarrassed as [he]113-mr. gray had been only a few minutes before , [I]0-i remember thinking [he]113-mr. gray looked almost as grand as [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady when [he]113-mr. gray spoke . “ [[Your]0-i ladyship]3058-your ladyship must remember that it may be [my]113-mr. gray duty to speak to [[my]113-mr. gray parishioners]3116-my parishioners on many subjects on which [they]3116-my parishioners do not agree with [me]113-mr. gray . [I]113-mr. gray am not at liberty to be silent , because [they]3116-my parishioners differ in opinion from [me]113-mr. gray . ”[113-mr. gray] [Lady Ludlow]92-lady ludlow ’s great blue eyes dilated with surprise , and — [I]0-i do think — anger , at being thus spoken to . [I]0-i am not sure whether it was very wise in [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . [He]113-mr. gray [himself]113-mr. gray looked afraid of the consequences but as if [he]113-mr. gray was determined to bear them without flinching . For a minute there was silence . Then [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady replied—“Mr .
