[Honour]154-honour was , to [her]3217-my poor lady , second nature , and [she]3217-my poor lady had never tried to find out on what principle its laws were based . So , telling [the lad]3210-the lad that [she]3217-my poor lady wished to see [Mr. Horner]238-mr. horner when [he]238-mr. horner returned from [Warwick]40-warwick , [she]3217-my poor lady dismissed [him]238-mr. horner with a despondent look ; [he]238-mr. horner , meanwhile , right glad to be out of the awful gentleness of [her]3217-my poor lady presence . “[0-i] What is to be done ? ” said [she]3217-my poor lady , half to [herself]3217-my poor lady and half to [me]0-i . [I]0-i could not answer , for [I]0-i was puzzled [myself]0-i . “[0-i] It was a right word , ” [she]3217-my poor lady continued , “[0-i] that [I]0-i used , when [I]0-i called reading and writing ‘ edge - tools . ’ If [our]1199-we lower orders have these edge - tools given to [them]1200-them , [we]1199-we shall have the terrible scenes of the French Revolution acted over again in [England]9-england . When [I]0-i was [a girl]304-a girl , [one]927-one never heard of the rights of [men]3110-men , [one only heard of the duties]1204-one only heard of the duties . Now , here was [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , only last night , talking of the right [every child]1205-every child had to instruction . [I]0-i could hardly keep [my]0-i patience with [him]113-mr. gray , and at length [we]1199-we fairly came to words ; and [I]0-i told [him]113-mr. gray [I]0-i would have no such thing as a Sunday - school ( or a Sabbath - school , as [he]113-mr. gray calls it , just like [a Jew]3063-a jew ) in [[my]0-i village]1207-my village . ” “[113-mr. gray] And what did [he]113-mr. gray say , [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ? ” [I]113-mr. gray asked ; for the struggle that seemed now to have come to a crisis , had been going on for some time in a quiet way . “[113-mr. gray] Why , [he]113-mr. gray gave way to temper , and said [he]113-mr. gray was bound to remember , [he]113-mr. gray was under [the bishop]560-the bishop ’s authority , not under [mine]0-i ; and implied that [he]113-mr. gray should persevere in [his]113-mr. gray designs , notwithstanding [my]0-i expressed opinion . ” “[336-my lady] And [[your]336-my lady ladyship]3058-your ladyship — ” [I]3058-your ladyship half inquired . “[3058-your ladyship] [I]0-i could only rise and curtsey , and civilly dismiss [him]113-mr. gray . When [two persons]1211-two persons have arrived at a certain point of expression on a subject , about which [they]1211-two persons differ as materially as [I]0-i do from [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray , the wisest course , if [they]1211-two persons wish to remain [friends]3176-friends , is to drop the conversation entirely and suddenly . It is one of the few cases where abruptness is desirable . ” [I]113-mr. gray was sorry for [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . [He]113-mr. gray had been to see [me]113-mr. gray several times , and had helped [me]113-mr. gray to bear [my]113-mr. gray illness in a better spirit than [I]113-mr. gray should have done without [his]113-mr. gray good advice and prayers . And [I]113-mr. gray had gathered from little things [he]113-mr. gray said , how much [his]113-mr. gray heart was set upon this new scheme . [I]113-mr. gray liked [him]113-mr. gray so much , and [I]113-mr. gray loved and respected [[my]113-mr. gray lady]336-my lady so well , that [I]113-mr. gray could not bear [them]336-my lady to be on the cool terms to which [they]336-my lady were constantly getting . Yet [I]113-mr. gray could do nothing but keep silence . [I]113-mr. gray suppose [[my]113-mr. gray lady]336-my lady understood something of what was passing in [my]113-mr. gray mind ; for , after a minute or two , [she]336-my lady went on : — “[113-mr. gray] If [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray knew all [I]0-i know,—if [he]113-mr. gray had [my]0-i experience , [he]113-mr. gray would not be so ready to speak of setting up [his]113-mr. gray new plans in opposition to [my]0-i judgment . Indeed , ” [she]336-my lady continued , lashing [herself]336-my lady up with [her]336-my lady own recollections , “[113-mr. gray] times are changed when [the parson of [a village]1214-a village]1213-the parson of a village comes to beard [the liege lady]1215-the liege lady in [[her]1215-the liege lady own house]1216-her own house . Why , in [[my]0-i grandfather]1217-my grandfather ’s days , [the parson]1218-the parson was [family chaplain]1219-family chaplain too , and dined at [the Hall]501-the hall every Sunday . [He]1218-the parson was helped last , and expected to have done first . [I]0-i remember seeing [him]1218-the parson take up [his]1218-the parson plate and knife and fork , and say with [his]1218-the parson mouth full all the time [he]1218-the parson was speaking : ‘ If [you]1221-you please , [Sir Urian]152-sir urian , and [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady , [I]0-i ’ll follow the beef into [[the housekeeper]1223-the housekeeper ’s room]1224-the housekeeper ’s room ; ’ for [you]1221-you see , unless [he]1218-the parson did so , [he]1218-the parson stood no chance of a second helping . [A greedy man]1225-a greedy man , [that parson]1226-that parson was , to be sure ! [I]0-i recollect [his]1218-the parson once eating up the whole of some little bird at dinner , and by way of diverting attention from [his]1218-the parson greediness , [he]1218-the parson told how [he]1218-the parson had heard that [a rook soaked in vinegar and then dressed in a particular way]1227-a rook soaked in vinegar and then dressed in a particular way , could not be distinguished from the bird [he]1218-the parson was then eating . [I]0-i saw by the grim look of [[my]0-i grandfather]1217-my grandfather ’s face that [the parson]1218-the parson ’s doing and saying displeased [him]1218-the parson ; and , child as [I]0-i was , [I]0-i had some notion of what was coming , when , as [I]0-i was riding out on [my]0-i little , white pony , by [[my]0-i grandfather]1217-my grandfather ’s side , the next Friday , [he]1218-the parson stopped one of [the gamekeepers]1231-the gamekeepers , and bade [him]1218-the parson shoot one of the oldest rooks [he]1218-the parson could find . [I]0-i knew no more about it till Sunday , when a dish was set right before [the parson]1218-the parson , and [Sir Urian]152-sir urian said : ‘ Now , [Parson Hemming]155-parson hemming , [I]0-i have had a rook shot , and soaked in vinegar , and dressed as [you]155-parson hemming described last Sunday . Fall to , [man]1233-man , and eat it with as good an appetite as [you]155-parson hemming had last Sunday . Pick the bones clean , or by — , no more Sunday dinners shall [you]155-parson hemming eat at [my]0-i table ! ’ [I]0-i gave one look at [poor Mr. Hemming]156-poor mr. hemming ’s face , as [he]156-poor mr. hemming tried to swallow the first morsel , and make believe as though [he]156-poor mr. hemming thought it very good ; but [I]0-i could not look again , for shame , although [[my]0-i grandfather]1217-my grandfather laughed , and kept asking [us]1235-us all round if [we]1235-us knew what could have become of [the parson]1218-the parson ’s appetite . ” “[1217-my grandfather] And did [he]1217-my grandfather finish it ? ” [I]1217-my grandfather asked . “[1217-my grandfather] O yes , [[my]0-i dear]3052-my dear . What [[my]0-i grandfather]1217-my grandfather said was to be done , was done always . [He]1217-my grandfather was [a terrible man in [his]1217-my grandfather anger]1239-a terrible man in his anger ! But to think of the difference between [Parson Hemming]155-parson hemming and [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray ! or even of poor dear [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford and [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . [Mr. Mountford]112-mr. mountford would never have withstood [me]0-i as [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray did ! ” “[113-mr. gray] And [[your]155-parson hemming ladyship]3058-your ladyship really thinks that it would not be right to have a Sunday - school ? ” [I]3058-your ladyship asked , feeling very timid as [I]3058-your ladyship put time question . “[3058-your ladyship] Certainly not . As [I]0-i told [Mr. Gray]113-mr. gray . [I]0-i consider a knowledge of the Creed , and of [the Lord]542-the lord ’s Prayer , as essential to salvation ; and that [any child]1242-any child may have , whose [parents]1243-parents bring it regularly to [church]668-church . Then there are the Ten Commandments , which teach simple duties in the plainest language . Of course , if [a lad]3207-a lad is taught to read and write ( as [that unfortunate boy]1246-that unfortunate boy has been who was [here]3173-here this morning ) [his]3207-a lad duties become complicated , and [his]3207-a lad temptations much greater , while , at the same time , [he]3207-a lad has no hereditary principles and honourable training to serve as safeguards . [I]0-i might take up [my]0-i old simile of the race - horse and cart - horse . [I]0-i am distressed , ” continued [she]0-i , with a break in [her]0-i ideas , “[0-i] about [that boy]1248-that boy . The whole thing reminds [me]0-i so much of a story of what happened to [a friend of [mine]0-i]1249-a friend of mine — [Clement de Crequy]195-pierre . Did [I]0-i ever tell [you]0-i about [him]195-pierre ? ” “[0-i] No , [[your]0-i ladyship]3058-your ladyship , ” [I]195-pierre replied . “[195-pierre] [Poor [Clement]195-pierre]1251-poor clement ! More than twenty years ago , [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow and [I]0-i spent a winter in [Paris]22-paris . [He]195-pierre had [many friends]1252-many friends [there]559-there ; perhaps not very good or [very wise men]1254-very wise men , but [he]195-pierre was so kind that [he]195-pierre liked [every one]1255-every one , and [every one]1255-every one liked [him]195-pierre . [We]1257-we had [an apartment]1258-an apartment , as [they]1259-they call it [there]559-there , in [the Rue de Lille]42-the rue de lille ; [we]1257-we had the first - floor of [a grand hotel]1261-a grand hotel , with the basement for [[our]1257-we servants]1262-our servants . On the floor above [us]1257-we [the owner of [the house]3047-the house]1263-the owner of the house lived , [a Marquise de Crequy]158-a marquise de crequy , [a widow]340-a widow . [They]1259-they tell [me]0-i that the Crequy coat - of - arms is still emblazoned , after all these terrible years , on a shield above [the arched porte - cochere]1266-the arched porte - cochere , just as it was then , though [the family]331-the family is quite extinct . [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy had only [one son]1268-one son , [Clement]195-pierre , who was just the same age as [[my]0-i Urian]1269-my urian — [you]1270-you may see [his]195-pierre portrait in [the great hall]453-the great hall — [Urian]152-sir urian ’s , [I]0-i mean . ” [I]1272-i knew that [Master Urian]160-urian had been drowned at [sea]3221-sea ; and often had [I]1272-i looked at the presentment of [his]160-urian bonny hopeful face , in [his]160-urian sailor ’s dress , with right hand outstretched to a ship on [the sea]1081-the sea in the distance , as if [he]160-urian had just said , “[1272-i] Look at [her]1272-i ! all [her]1272-i sails are set , and [I]0-i ’m just off . ” [Poor Master Urian]160-urian ! [he]160-urian went down in [this very ship]3223-this very ship not a year after the picture was taken ! But now [I]0-i will go back to [[my]0-i lady]336-my lady ’s story . “[0-i] [I]0-i can see [those two boys]1273-those two boys playing now , ” continued [she]0-i , softly , shutting [her]0-i eyes , as if the better to call up the vision , “[1273-those two boys] as [they]1273-those two boys used to do five - and - twenty years ago in [those old - fashioned French gardens behind [[our]1275-our hotel]1276-our hotel]1274-those old - fashioned french gardens behind our hotel . Many a time have [I]0-i watched them from [my]0-i windows . It was , perhaps , a better play - place than [an English garden]1277-an english garden would have been , for there were but few flower - beds , and no lawn at all to speak about ; but , instead , terraces and balustrades and vases and flights of stone steps more in the Italian style ; and there were jets - d’eau , and little fountains that could be set playing by turning water - cocks that were hidden here and there . How [Clement]195-pierre delighted in turning the water on to surprise [Urian]160-urian , and how gracefully [he]195-pierre did the honours , as it were , to [[my]0-i dear , rough , [sailor lad]1279-sailor lad]1278-my dear , rough , sailor lad ! [Urian]160-urian was as dark as [a gipsy boy]1280-a gipsy boy , and cared little for [his]160-urian appearance , and resisted all [my]0-i efforts at setting off [his]160-urian black eyes and tangled curls ; but [Clement]195-pierre , without ever showing that [he]195-pierre thought about [himself]195-pierre and [his]195-pierre dress , was always dainty and elegant , even though [his]195-pierre clothes were sometimes but threadbare . [He]160-urian used to be dressed in a kind of [hunter]1281-hunter ’s green suit , open at the neck and half - way down the chest to beautiful old lace frills ; [his]160-urian long golden curls fell behind just like [a girl]304-a girl ’s , and [his]160-urian hair in front was cut over [his]160-urian straight dark eyebrows in a line almost as straight . [Urian]160-urian learnt more of [a gentleman]1283-a gentleman ’s carefulness and propriety of appearance from [that lad]1284-that lad in two months than [he]160-urian had done in years from all [my]0-i lectures . [I]0-i recollect one day , when [the two boys]1285-the two boys were in full romp — and , [my]0-i window being open , [I]0-i could hear [them]1285-the two boys perfectly — and [Urian]160-urian was daring [Clement]195-pierre to some scrambling or climbing , which [Clement]195-pierre refused to undertake , but in a hesitating way , as though [he]160-urian longed to do it if some reason had not stood in the way ; and at times , [Urian]160-urian , who was [hasty and thoughtless , poor fellow]1286-hasty and thoughtless , poor fellow , told [Clement]195-pierre that [he]160-urian was afraid . ‘ Fear ! ’ said [the French boy]1287-the french boy , drawing [himself]1287-the french boy up ; ‘ [you]160-urian do not know what [you]160-urian say . If [you]160-urian will be here at six to - morrow morning , when it is only just light , [I]0-i will take that starling ’s nest on [the top of yonder chimney]1288-the top of yonder chimney . ’ ‘ But why not now , [Clement]195-pierre ? ’ said [Urian]160-urian , putting [his]160-urian arm round [Clement]195-pierre ’s neck . ‘ Why then , and not now , just when [we]1289-we are in the humour for it ? ’ ‘ Because [we]1289-we [De Crequys]161-the de crequys are poor , and [[my]0-i mother]312-my mother can not afford [me]0-i another suit of clothes this year , and yonder stone carving is all jagged , and would tear [my]0-i coat and breeches . Now , to - morrow morning [I]0-i could go up with nothing on but an old shirt . ’ “ ‘ But [you]160-urian would tear [your]160-urian legs . ’ “[3214-the boy] ‘ [[My]0-i race]1291-my race do not care for pain , ’ said [the boy]3214-the boy , drawing [himself]3214-the boy from [Urian]160-urian ’s arm , and walking a few steps away , with a becoming pride and reserve ; for [he]3214-the boy was hurt at being spoken to as if [he]3214-the boy were afraid , and annoyed at having to confess the true reason for declining the feat . But [Urian]160-urian was not to be thus baffled . [He]160-urian went up to [Clement]195-pierre , and put [his]160-urian arm once more about [his]195-pierre neck , and [I]0-i could see [the two lads]1293-the two lads as [they]1293-the two lads walked down [the terrace]908-the terrace away from [the hotel]1295-the hotel windows : first [Urian]160-urian spoke eagerly , looking with imploring fondness into [Clement]195-pierre ’s face , which sought the ground , till at last [the French boy]1287-the french boy spoke , and by - and - by [his]1287-the french boy arm was round [Urian]160-urian too , and [they]1293-the two lads paced backwards and forwards in deep talk , but gravely , as became [men]3110-men , rather than [boys]1298-boys . “ All at once , from [the little chapel at the corner of [the large garden belonging to [the Missions Etrangeres]3227-the missions etrangeres]3226-the large garden belonging to the missions etrangeres]3225-the little chapel at the corner of the large garden belonging to the missions etrangeres , [I]1293-the two lads heard the tinkle of the little bell , announcing the elevation of [the host]3228-the host . Down on [his]195-pierre knees went [Clement]195-pierre , hands crossed , eyes bent down : while [Urian]160-urian stood looking on in respectful thought . “[1293-the two lads] What a friendship that might have been ! [I]0-i never dream of [Urian]160-urian without seeing [Clement]195-pierre too — [Urian]160-urian speaks to [me]0-i , or does something,—but [Clement]195-pierre only flits round [Urian]160-urian , and never seems to see [any one else]1077-any one else ! ” “[195-pierre] But [I]0-i must not forget to tell [you]1300-you , that the next morning , before [he]160-urian was out of [[his]160-urian room]1301-his room , [a footman of [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ’s]1302-a footman of madame de crequy ’s brought [Urian]160-urian the starling ’s nest . ” “[1302-a footman of madame de crequy ’s] Well ! [we]1303-we came back to [England]9-england , and [the boys]1304-the boys were to correspond ; and [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy and [I]0-i exchanged civilities ; and [Urian]160-urian went to [sea]3221-sea . ” “[160-urian] After that , all seemed to drop away . [I]0-i can not tell [you]1300-you all . However , to confine [myself]0-i to [the De Crequys]161-the de crequys . [I]0-i had a letter from [Clement]195-pierre ; [I]0-i knew [he]195-pierre felt [[his]195-pierre friend]1306-his friend ’s death deeply ; but [I]0-i should never have learnt it from the letter [he]195-pierre sent . It was formal , and seemed like chaff to [my]0-i hungering heart . [Poor fellow]1307-poor fellow ! [I]0-i dare say [he]195-pierre had found it hard to write . What could [he]195-pierre — or [any one]624-any one — say to [a mother who has lost [her]1309-a mother who has lost her child child]1309-a mother who has lost her child ? [The world]866-the world does not think so , and , in general , [one]927-one must conform to the customs of [the world]866-the world ; but , judging from [my]0-i own experience , [I]0-i should say that reverent silence at such times is the tenderest balm . [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy wrote too . But [I]0-i knew [she]169-madame de crequy could not feel [my]0-i loss so much as [Clement]195-pierre , and therefore [her]169-madame de crequy letter was not such a disappointment . [She]169-madame de crequy and [I]0-i went on being civil and polite in the way of commissions , and occasionally introducing [friends]3176-friends to [each other]780-each other , for a year or two , and then [we]1315-we ceased to have any intercourse . Then the terrible Revolution came . [No one who did not live at those times]1316-no one who did not live at those times can imagine the daily expectation of news — the hourly terror of rumours affecting the fortunes and lives of [those whom most of [us]1315-we had known as [pleasant hosts]1318-pleasant hosts , receiving [us]1315-we with peaceful welcome in [[their]1317-those whom most of us had known as pleasant hosts , receiving us with peaceful welcome in their magnificent houses magnificent houses]1319-their magnificent houses]1317-those whom most of us had known as pleasant hosts , receiving us with peaceful welcome in their magnificent houses . Of course , there was sin enough and suffering enough behind the scenes ; but [[we]1315-we English visitors to [Paris]22-paris]1320-we english visitors to paris had seen little or nothing of that,—and [I]0-i had sometimes thought , indeed , how even death seemed loth to choose [[his]195-pierre victims]1321-his victims out of [that brilliant throng whom [I]0-i had known]1322-that brilliant throng whom i had known . [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ’s [one boy]1323-one boy lived ; while [three out of [my]0-i six]1324-three out of my six were gone since [we]1315-we had met ! [I]0-i do not think all lots are equal , even now that [I]0-i know the end of [her]169-madame de crequy hopes ; but [I]0-i do say that whatever [our]1315-we individual lot is , it is [our]1315-we duty to accept it , without comparing it with that of [others]3078-others . “ The times were thick with gloom and terror . ‘ What next ? ’ was the question [we]1315-we asked of [every one who brought [us]1315-we news from [Paris]22-paris]3229-every one who brought us news from paris . Where were these demons hidden when , so few years ago , [we]1315-we danced and feasted , and enjoyed the brilliant salons and the charming friendships of [Paris]22-paris ? “[3081-my lord] One evening , [I]0-i was sitting alone in [Saint James ’s Square]43-saint james ’s square ; [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord off at [the club]1327-the club with [Mr. Fox]162-mr. fox and [others]3078-others : [he]3081-my lord had left [me]0-i , thinking that [I]0-i should go to [one of [the many places to which [I]0-i had been invited for that evening]1330-the many places to which i had been invited for that evening]1329-one of the many places to which i had been invited for that evening ; but [I]0-i had no heart to go anywhere , for it was [poor Urian]160-urian ’s birthday , and [I]0-i had not even rung for lights , though the day was fast closing in , but was thinking over all [his]3081-my lord pretty ways , and on [his]3081-my lord warm affectionate nature , and how often [I]0-i had been too hasty in speaking to [him]3081-my lord , for all [I]0-i loved [him]3081-my lord so dearly ; and how [I]0-i seemed to have neglected and dropped [[his]3081-my lord dear friend [Clement]195-pierre , who might even now be in need of help in [that cruel , bloody]1332-that cruel , bloody [Paris]22-paris]1331-his dear friend clement , who might even now be in need of help in that cruel , bloody paris . [I]0-i say [I]0-i was thinking reproachfully of all this , and particularly of [Clement de Crequy]195-pierre in connection with [Urian]160-urian , when [Fenwick]163-fenwick brought [me]0-i a note , sealed with a coat - of - arms [I]0-i knew well , though [I]0-i could not remember at the moment where [I]0-i had seen it . [I]0-i puzzled over it , as [one]927-one does sometimes , for a minute or more , before [I]0-i opened the letter . In a moment [I]0-i saw it was from [Clement de Crequy]195-pierre . ‘ [[My]0-i mother]312-my mother is here , ’ [he]195-pierre said : ‘ [she]312-my mother is very ill , and [I]0-i am bewildered in [this strange country]1335-this strange country . May [I]0-i entreat [you]0-i to receive [me]0-i for a few minutes ? ’ [The bearer of the note]1336-the bearer of the note was [the woman of [the house]3047-the house where [they]1339-their lodged]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged . [I]0-i had [her]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged brought up into [the anteroom]1340-the anteroom , and questioned [her]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged [myself]0-i , while [[my]0-i carriage]1341-my carriage was being brought round . [They]1339-their had arrived in [London]2-london a fortnight or so before : [she]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged had not known [their]1339-their quality , judging [them]1339-their ( according to [her]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged kind ) by [their]1339-their dress and [their]1339-their luggage ; poor enough , no doubt . [The lady]1342-the lady had never left [her]1342-the lady bed - room since [her]1342-the lady arrival ; [the young man]1343-the young man waited upon [her]1342-the lady , did everything for [her]1342-the lady , never left [her]1342-the lady , in fact ; only [she]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged ( [the messenger]1344-the messenger ) had promised to stay within call , as soon as [she]1337-the woman of the house where they lodged returned , while [he]1343-the young man went out somewhere . [She]1342-the lady could hardly understand [him]1343-the young man , [he]1343-the young man spoke English so badly . [He]1343-the young man had never spoken it , [I]0-i dare say , since [he]1343-the young man had talked to [[my]0-i Urian]1269-my urian . ” CHAPTER V. “[1343-the young man] In the hurry of the moment [I]0-i scarce knew what [I]0-i did . [I]0-i bade [the housekeeper]1223-the housekeeper put up every delicacy [she]1223-the housekeeper had , in order to tempt [the invalid]1347-the invalid , whom yet [I]0-i hoped to bring back with [me]0-i to [[our]1348-they house]1349-our house . When [the carriage]800-the carriage was ready [I]0-i took [the good woman]1351-the good woman with [me]0-i to show [us]1348-they the exact way , which [[my]0-i coachman]1352-my coachman professed not to know ; for , indeed , [they]1348-they were staying at but a poor kind of place at [the back of [Leicester Square]44-leicester square]1353-the back of leicester square , of which [they]1348-they had heard , as [Clement]195-pierre told [me]0-i afterwards , from [one of [the fishermen who had carried [them]1348-they across from [the Dutch coast]1356-the dutch coast]1355-the fishermen who had carried them across from the dutch coast in [their]1348-they disguises as [a Friesland peasant]1357-a friesland peasant and [[his]1357-a friesland peasant mother]1358-his mother]1354-one of the fishermen who had carried them across from the dutch coast in their disguises as a friesland peasant and his mother . [They]1348-they had some jewels of value concealed round [[their]1348-they persons]1359-their persons ; but [their]1348-they ready money was all spent before [I]0-i saw [them]1348-they , and [Clement]195-pierre had been unwilling to leave [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother , even for the time necessary to ascertain the best mode of disposing of the diamonds . For , overcome with distress of mind and bodily fatigue , [she]1358-his mother had reached [London]2-london only to take to [[her]1358-his mother bed]1361-her bed in a sort of low , nervous fever , in which [her]1358-his mother chief and only idea seemed to be that [Clement]195-pierre was about to be taken from [her]1358-his mother to [some prison]1362-some prison or other ; and if [he]195-pierre were out of [her]1358-his mother sight , though but for a minute , [she]1358-his mother cried like [a child]773-a child , and could not be pacified or comforted . [The landlady]1364-the landlady was [a kind , good woman]1365-a kind , good woman , and though [she]1364-the landlady but half understood the case , [she]1364-the landlady was truly sorry for [them]1366-them , as [foreigners]1367-foreigners , and [the mother sick in [a strange land]1369-a strange land]1368-the mother sick in a strange land . “ [I]1364-the landlady sent [her]1364-the landlady forwards to request permission for [my]1364-the landlady entrance . In a moment [I]1364-the landlady saw [Clement]195-pierre — [a tall , elegant young man , in a curious dress of coarse cloth , standing at the open door of [a room]3231-a room]3230-a tall , elegant young man , in a curious dress of coarse cloth , standing at the open door of a room , and evidently — even before [he]195-pierre accosted [me]1364-the landlady — striving to soothe the terrors of [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother inside . [I]1364-the landlady went towards [him]195-pierre , and would have taken [his]195-pierre hand , but [he]195-pierre bent down and kissed [mine]1364-the landlady . “[1364-the landlady] ‘ May [I]0-i come in , [madame]1370-madame ? ’ [I]0-i asked , looking at [the poor sick lady]1371-the poor sick lady , lying in the dark , dingy bed , [her]1371-the poor sick lady head propped up on coarse and dirty pillows , and gazing with affrighted eyes at all that was going on . “ ‘ [Clement]195-pierre ! [Clement]195-pierre ! come to [me]1372-he ! ’ [she]1371-the poor sick lady cried ; and when [he]1372-he went to the bedside [she]1371-the poor sick lady turned on one side , and took [his]1372-he hand in both of [hers]1371-the poor sick lady , and began stroking it , and looking up in [his]1372-he face . [I]1372-he could scarce keep back [my]1372-he tears . “[1372-he] [He]1372-he stood there quite still , except that from time to time [he]1372-he spoke to [her]1371-the poor sick lady in a low tone . At last [I]0-i advanced into [the room]489-the room , so that [I]0-i could talk to [him]1372-he , without renewing [her]1371-the poor sick lady alarm . [I]0-i asked for [the doctor]3071-the doctor ’s address ; for [I]0-i had heard that [they]1375-they had called in some one , at [[their]1375-they landlady]1376-their landlady ’s recommendation : but [I]0-i could hardly understand [Clement]195-pierre ’s broken English , and mispronunciation of [our]1377-our proper names , and was obliged to apply to [the woman]1378-the woman [herself]1378-the woman . [I]0-i could not say much to [Clement]195-pierre , for [his]195-pierre attention was perpetually needed by [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother , who never seemed to perceive that [I]0-i was [there]559-there . But [I]0-i told [him]195-pierre not to fear , however long [I]0-i might be away , for that [I]0-i would return before night ; and , bidding [the woman]1378-the woman take charge of all the heterogeneous things [the housekeeper]1223-the housekeeper had put up , and leaving one of [[my]0-i men]1383-my men in [the house]3047-the house , who could understand a few words of French , with directions that [he]195-pierre was to hold [himself]195-pierre at [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ’s orders until [I]0-i sent or gave [him]195-pierre fresh commands , [I]0-i drove off to [[the doctor]3071-the doctor ’s]1386-the doctor ’s . What [I]0-i wanted was [his]1386-the doctor ’s permission to remove [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy to [[my]0-i own house]1387-my own house , and to learn how it best could be done ; for [I]0-i saw that every movement in [the room]489-the room , every sound except [Clement]195-pierre ’s voice , brought on a fresh access of trembling and nervous agitation . “ [The doctor]3071-the doctor was , [I]0-i should think , [a clever man]3234-a clever man ; but [he]3071-the doctor had that kind of abrupt manner which [people]302-people get who have much to do with the lower orders . “[0-i] [I]0-i told [him]1386-the doctor ’s the story of [[his]1386-the doctor ’s patient]1389-his patient , the interest [I]0-i had in [her]1389-his patient , and the wish [I]0-i entertained of removing [her]1389-his patient to [[my]0-i own house]1387-my own house . “ ‘ It ca n’t be done , ’ said [he]1386-the doctor ’s . ‘ Any change will kill [her]1389-his patient . ’ “[0-i] ‘ But it must be done , ’ [I]0-i replied . ‘ And it shall not kill [her]1389-his patient . ’ “ ‘ Then [I]0-i have nothing more to say , ’ said [he]1386-the doctor ’s , turning away from the carriage door , and making as though [he]1386-the doctor ’s would go back into [the house]3047-the house . “[0-i] ‘ Stop a moment . [You]0-i must help [me]0-i ; and , if [you]0-i do , [you]0-i shall have reason to be glad , for [I]0-i will give [you]0-i fifty pounds down with pleasure . If [you]0-i wo n’t do it , another shall . ’ “ [He]1386-the doctor ’s looked at [me]1391-i , then ( furtively ) at [the carriage]800-the carriage , hesitated , and then said : ‘ [You]1391-i do not mind expense , apparently . [I]1391-i suppose [you]1391-i are [a rich lady of quality]3238-a rich lady of quality . [Such folks]3239-such folks will not stick at such trifles as the life or death of [a sick woman]3240-a sick woman to get [their]3239-such folks own way . [I]1391-i suppose [I]1391-i must e’en help [you]1391-i , for if [I]1391-i do n’t , another will . ’ “[1391-i] [I]0-i did not mind what [he]1391-i said , so that [he]1391-i would assist [me]0-i . [I]0-i was pretty sure that [she]1392-her was in a state to require opiates ; and [I]0-i had not forgotten [Christopher Sly]164-christopher sly , [you]1393-you may be sure , so [I]0-i told [him]1391-i what [I]0-i had in [my]0-i head . That in the dead of night — the quiet time in [the streets,—she]1394-the streets,—she should be carried in a hospital litter , softly and warmly covered over , from [the Leicester Square lodging - house]1395-the leicester square lodging - house to [rooms that [I]0-i would have in perfect readiness for [her]1392-her]1396-rooms that i would have in perfect readiness for her . As [I]0-i planned , so it was done . [I]0-i let [Clement]195-pierre know , by a note , of [my]0-i design . [I]0-i had all prepared at [home]586-home , and [we]1398-we walked about [[my]0-i house]1399-my house as though shod with velvet , while [the porter]1400-the porter watched at the open door . At last , through the darkness , [I]0-i saw the lanterns carried by [[my]0-i men]1383-my men , who were leading [the little procession]1402-the little procession . The litter looked like a hearse ; on one side walked [the doctor]3071-the doctor , on the other [Clement]195-pierre ; [they]1383-my men came softly and swiftly along . [I]0-i could not try any farther experiment ; [we]1398-we dared not change [her]1392-her clothes ; [she]1392-her was laid in the bed in [the landlady]1364-the landlady ’s coarse night - gear , and covered over warmly , and left in [the shaded , scented room]1405-the shaded , scented room , with [a nurse]869-a nurse and [the doctor]3071-the doctor watching by [her]1392-her , while [I]0-i led [Clement]195-pierre to [the dressing - room adjoining , in which [I]0-i had had a bed placed for [him]195-pierre]1408-the dressing - room adjoining , in which i had had a bed placed for him . Farther than that [he]195-pierre would not go ; and there [I]0-i had refreshments brought . Meanwhile , [he]195-pierre had shown [his]195-pierre gratitude by every possible action ( for [we]1398-we none of [us]1398-we dared to speak ): [he]195-pierre had kneeled at [my]0-i feet , and kissed [my]0-i hand , and left it wet with [his]195-pierre tears . [He]195-pierre had thrown up [his]195-pierre arms to [Heaven]165-heaven , and prayed earnestly , as [I]0-i could see by the movement of [his]195-pierre lips . [I]0-i allowed [him]195-pierre to relieve [himself]195-pierre by these dumb expressions , if [I]0-i may so call them,—and then [I]0-i left [him]195-pierre , and went to [[my]0-i own rooms]1409-my own rooms to sit up for [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord , and tell [him]195-pierre what [I]0-i had done . “ Of course , it was all right ; and neither [[my]3081-my lord lord]3081-my lord nor [I]3081-my lord could sleep for wondering how [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy would bear [her]169-madame de crequy awakening . [I]3081-my lord had engaged [the doctor]3071-the doctor , to whose face and voice [she]169-madame de crequy was accustomed , to remain with [her]169-madame de crequy all night : [the nurse]3243-the nurse was experienced , and [Clement]195-pierre was within call . But it was with the greatest relief that [I]3081-my lord heard from [[my]3081-my lord own woman]3244-my own woman , when [she]3244-my own woman brought [me]3081-my lord [my]3081-my lord chocolate , that [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ( [Monsieur]3245-monsieur had said ) had awakened more tranquil than [she]169-madame de crequy had been for many days . To be sure , the whole aspect of [the bed - chamber]3246-the bed - chamber must have been more familiar to [her]169-madame de crequy than [the miserable place where [I]3081-my lord had found [her]169-madame de crequy]3247-the miserable place where i had found her , and [she]169-madame de crequy must have intuitively felt [herself]169-madame de crequy among [friends]3176-friends . “[3081-my lord] [[My]0-i lord]3081-my lord was scandalized at [Clement]195-pierre ’s dress , which , after the first moment of seeing [him]195-pierre [I]0-i had forgotten , in thinking of other things , and for which [I]0-i had not prepared [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow . [He]3081-my lord sent for [[his]3081-my lord own tailor]1412-his own tailor , and bade [him]1412-his own tailor bring patterns of stuffs , and engage [[his]3081-my lord men]1413-his men to work night and day till [Clement]195-pierre could appear as became [his]195-pierre rank . In short , in a few days so much of the traces of [their]1413-his men flight were removed , that [we]1414-our had almost forgotten the terrible causes of it , and rather felt as if [they]1413-his men had come on a visit to [us]1414-our than that [they]1413-his men had been compelled to fly [[their]1413-his men country]1415-their country . [Their]1413-his men diamonds , too , were sold well by [[[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord ’s agents]1417-my lord ’s agents , though [the London shops]1418-the london shops were stocked with jewellery , and such portable valuables , some of rare and curious fashion , which were sold for half [their]1413-his men real value by [emigrants who could not afford to wait]1419-emigrants who could not afford to wait . [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy was recovering [her]169-madame de crequy health , although [her]169-madame de crequy strength was sadly gone , and [she]169-madame de crequy would never be equal to such another flight , as the perilous one which [she]169-madame de crequy had gone through , and to which [she]169-madame de crequy could not bear the slightest reference . For some time things continued in [this state]1420-this state — [the De Crequys]161-the de crequys still [[our]1414-our honoured [visitors,—many houses besides [our]1414-our own]1422-visitors,—many houses besides our own , even among [[our]1414-our own friends]1423-our own friends , open to receive [the poor flying nobility of [France]45-france]1424-the poor flying nobility of france , driven from [[their]1424-the poor flying nobility of france country]1415-their country by [the brutal republicans]1426-the brutal republicans , and [every freshly - arrived emigrant]1427-every freshly - arrived emigrant bringing new tales of horror , as if [these revolutionists]1428-these revolutionists were drunk with blood , and mad to devise new atrocities]1421-our honoured visitors,—many houses besides our own , even among our own friends , open to receive the poor flying nobility of france , driven from their country by the brutal republicans , and every freshly - arrived emigrant bringing new tales of horror , as if these revolutionists were drunk with blood , and mad to devise new atrocities . One day [Clement]195-pierre — [I]0-i should tell [you]1429-you [he]195-pierre had been presented to [[our]1414-our good King [George]126-george]1430-our good king george and [the sweet Queen]1431-the sweet queen , and [they]1432-they had accosted [him]195-pierre most graciously , and [his]195-pierre beauty and elegance , and some of the circumstances attendant on [his]195-pierre flight , made [him]195-pierre be received in [the world]866-the world quite like [a hero of romance]1434-a hero of romance ; [he]195-pierre might have been on intimate terms in many [a distinguished house]1435-a distinguished house , had [he]195-pierre cared to visit much ; but [he]195-pierre accompanied [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord and [me]0-i with an air of indifference and languor , which [I]0-i sometimes fancied made [him]195-pierre be all the more sought after : [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven ( that was the title [[my]0-i eldest son]1437-my eldest son bore ) tried in vain to interest [him]195-pierre in [all young men]1438-all young men ’s sports . But no ! it was the same through all . [[His]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother took far more interest in the on - dits of [the [London]2-london world]1440-the london world , into which [she]1358-his mother was far too great [an invalid]1441-an invalid to venture , than [he]195-pierre did in the absolute events themselves , in which [he]195-pierre might have been [an actor]1442-an actor . One day , as [I]0-i was saying , [an old Frenchman of a humble class]1443-an old frenchman of a humble class presented [himself]1443-an old frenchman of a humble class to [[our]1444-our servants]1262-our servants , [several of [them]1262-our servants]1446-several of them , understood French ; and through [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott , [I]0-i learnt that [he]1443-an old frenchman of a humble class was in some way connected with [the De Crequys]161-the de crequys ; not with [their]161-the de crequys [Paris]22-paris - life ; but [I]0-i fancy [he]1443-an old frenchman of a humble class had been intendant of [[their]161-the de crequys estates in [the country]1448-the country]1447-their estates in the country ; estates which were more useful as [hunting - grounds]1449-hunting - grounds than as adding to [their]161-the de crequys income . However , there was [the old man]1450-the old man and with [him]1450-the old man , wrapped round [his]1450-the old man person , [he]1450-the old man had brought the long parchment rolls , and deeds relating to [their]161-the de crequys property . These [he]1450-the old man would deliver up to none but [Monsieur de Crequy]167-monsieur de crequy , [the rightful owner]1451-the rightful owner ; and [Clement]195-pierre was out with [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven , so [the old man]1450-the old man waited ; and when [Clement]195-pierre came in , [I]0-i told [him]195-pierre of [the steward]1031-the steward ’s arrival , and how [he]195-pierre had been cared for by [[my]0-i people]1454-my people . [Clement]195-pierre went directly to see [him]195-pierre . [He]195-pierre was a long time away , and [I]0-i was waiting for [him]195-pierre to drive out with [me]0-i , for some purpose or another , [I]0-i scarce know what , but [I]0-i remember [I]0-i was tired of waiting , and was just in the act of ringing the bell to desire that [he]195-pierre might be reminded of [his]195-pierre engagement with [me]0-i , when [he]195-pierre came in , [his]195-pierre face as white as the powder in [his]195-pierre hair , [his]195-pierre beautiful eyes dilated with horror . [I]0-i saw that [he]195-pierre had heard something that touched [him]195-pierre even more closely than the usual tales which [every fresh emigrant]1455-every fresh emigrant brought . “ ‘ What is it , [Clement]195-pierre ? ’ [I]195-pierre asked . “[195-pierre] [He]195-pierre clasped [his]195-pierre hands , and looked as though [he]195-pierre tried to speak , but could not bring out the words . “ ‘ [They]3249-they have guillotined [[my]195-pierre uncle]3250-my uncle ! ’ said [he]195-pierre at last . Now , [I]195-pierre knew that there was [a Count]3251-a count [de Crequy]195-pierre ; but [I]195-pierre had always understood that [the elder branch]3252-the elder branch held very little communication with [him]3251-a count ; in fact , that [he]3251-a count was [a vaurien of some kind]3253-a vaurien of some kind , and rather a disgrace than otherwise to [the family]331-the family . So , perhaps , [I]195-pierre was hard - hearted but [I]195-pierre was a little surprised at this excess of emotion , till [I]195-pierre saw that peculiar look in [his]195-pierre eyes that [many people]3255-many people have when there is more terror in [their]3255-many people hearts than [they]3255-many people dare put into words . [He]195-pierre wanted [me]195-pierre to understand something without [his]195-pierre saying it ; but how could [I]195-pierre ? [I]195-pierre had never heard of [a Mademoiselle de Crequy]168-virginie . “[195-pierre] ‘ [Virginie]168-virginie ! ’ at last [he]1456-i uttered . In an instant [I]0-i understood it all , and remembered that , if [Urian]160-urian had lived , [he]160-urian too might have been in love . “ ‘ [[[Your]0-i uncle]3256-your uncle ’s daughter]3257-your uncle ’s daughter ? ’ [I]1456-i inquired . “[1456-i] ‘ [[My]0-i cousin]1457-my cousin , ’ [he]1456-i replied . “ [I]1456-i did not say , ‘ [[your]1456-i betrothed]3258-your betrothed , ’ but [I]1456-i had no doubt of it . [I]1456-i was mistaken , however . “[1456-i] ‘ O [madame]1370-madame ! ’ [he]1456-i continued , ‘ [[her]1457-my cousin mother]539-her mother died long ago — [[her]1457-my cousin father]1460-her father now — and [she]1457-my cousin is in daily fear,—alone , deserted — ’ “ ‘ Is [she]1457-my cousin in [the Abbaye]47-the abbaye ? ’ asked [I.]1456-i “[1456-i] ‘ No ! [she]1457-my cousin is in hiding with the widow of [[[her]1457-my cousin father]1460-her father ’s old concierge]1462-her father ’s old concierge . Any day [they]1463-they may search [the house]3047-the house for [aristocrats]1465-aristocrats . [They]1463-they are seeking [them]1465-aristocrats everywhere . Then , not [her]1457-my cousin life alone , but that of [the old woman]1466-the old woman , [[her]1457-my cousin hostess]1467-her hostess , is sacrificed . [The old woman]1466-the old woman knows this , and trembles with fear . Even if [she]1466-the old woman is brave enough to be faithful , [her]1466-the old woman fears would betray [her]1466-the old woman , should [the house]3047-the house be searched . Yet , there is [no one]590-no one to help [Virginie]168-virginie to escape . [She]1457-my cousin is alone in [Paris]22-paris . ’ “ [I]1457-my cousin saw what was in [his]3259-his mind . [He]3259-his was fretting and chafing to go to [[his]3259-his cousin]3260-his cousin ’s assistance ; but the thought of [[his]3259-his mother]1358-his mother restrained [him]3259-his . [I]1457-my cousin would not have kept back [Urian]160-urian from such on errand at such a time . How should [I]1457-my cousin restrain [him]3259-his ? And yet , perhaps , [I]1457-my cousin did wrong in not urging the chances of danger more . Still , if it was danger to [him]3259-his , was it not the same or even greater danger to [her?—for]3262-her?—for [the French]111-the french spared neither age nor sex in those wicked days of terror . So [I]1457-my cousin rather fell in with [his]3259-his wish , and encouraged [him]3259-his to think how best and most prudently it might be fulfilled ; never doubting , as [I]1457-my cousin have said , that [he]3259-his and [[his]3259-his cousin]3260-his cousin were troth - plighted . “[1457-my cousin] But when [I]0-i went to [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy — after [he]1471-he had imparted [his]1471-he , or rather [our]1472-our plan to [her]169-madame de crequy — [I]0-i found out [my]0-i mistake . [She]169-madame de crequy , who was in general too feeble to walk across [the room]489-the room save slowly , and with a stick , was going from end to end with quick , tottering steps ; and , if now and then [she]169-madame de crequy sank upon a chair , it seemed as if [she]169-madame de crequy could not rest , for [she]169-madame de crequy was up again in a moment , pacing along , wringing [her]169-madame de crequy hands , and speaking rapidly to [herself]169-madame de crequy . When [she]169-madame de crequy saw [me]0-i , [she]169-madame de crequy stopped : ‘ [Madame]1370-madame , ’ [she]169-madame de crequy said , ‘ [you]1370-madame have lost [[your]1370-madame own boy]1475-your own boy . [You]1370-madame might have left [me]0-i mine . ’ “ [I]169-madame de crequy was so astonished — [I]169-madame de crequy hardly knew what to say . [I]169-madame de crequy had spoken to [Clement]195-pierre as if [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother ’s consent were secure ( as [I]169-madame de crequy had felt [my]169-madame de crequy own would have been if [Urian]160-urian had been alive to ask it ) . Of coarse , both [he]195-pierre and [I]169-madame de crequy knew that [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother ’s consent must be asked and obtained , before [he]195-pierre could leave [her]1358-his mother to go on such an undertaking ; but , somehow , [my]169-madame de crequy blood always rose at the sight or sound of danger ; perhaps , because [my]169-madame de crequy life had been so peaceful . [Poor Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ! it was otherwise with [her]1358-his mother ; [she]1358-his mother despaired while [I]169-madame de crequy hoped , and [Clement]195-pierre trusted . “[169-madame de crequy] ‘ [Dear Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy , ’ said [I]0-i , ‘ [he]1476-he will return safely to [us]1477-us ; every precaution shall be taken , that either [he]1476-he or [you]0-i , or [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord , or [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven can think of ; but [he]1476-he can not leave [a girl]304-a girl — [[his]1476-he nearest relation]1480-his nearest relation save [you]0-i — [[his]1476-he betrothed]1481-his betrothed , is [she]1481-his betrothed not ? ’ “ ‘ [[His]1476-he betrothed]1481-his betrothed ! ’ cried [she]169-madame de crequy , now at the utmost pitch of [her]169-madame de crequy excitement . ‘ [Virginie]168-virginie betrothed to [Clement?—no]170-clement?—no ! thank heaven , not so bad as that ! Yet it might have been . But [mademoiselle]168-virginie scorned [[my]195-pierre son]3267-my son ! [She]168-virginie would have nothing to do with [him]195-pierre . Now is the time for [him]195-pierre to have nothing to do with [her]168-virginie ! ’ “[195-pierre] [Clement]195-pierre had entered at the door behind [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother as [she]1358-his mother thus spoke . [His]195-pierre face was set and pale , till it looked as gray and immovable as if it had been carved in stone . [He]195-pierre came forward and stood before [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother . [She]1358-his mother stopped [her]1358-his mother walk , threw back [her]1358-his mother haughty head , and [the two]1484-the two looked [each other]780-each other steadily in the face . After a minute or two in this attitude , [her]1358-his mother proud and resolute gaze never flinching or wavering , [he]195-pierre went down upon one knee , and , taking [her]1358-his mother hand — [her]1358-his mother hard , stony hand , which never closed on [his]195-pierre , but remained straight and stiff : “ ‘ [Mother]393-mother , ’ [he]195-pierre pleaded , ‘ withdraw [your]393-mother prohibition . Let [me]195-pierre go ! ’ “[195-pierre] ‘ What were [her]1358-his mother words ? ’ [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy replied , slowly , as if forcing [her]169-madame de crequy memory to the extreme of accuracy . ‘ [[My]0-i cousin]1457-my cousin , ’ [she]0-i said , ‘ when [I]0-i marry , [I]0-i marry [a man]725-a man , not [a petit - maitre]1488-a petit - maitre . [I]0-i marry [a man who , whatever [his]1489-a man who , whatever his rank may be rank may be]1489-a man who , whatever his rank may be will add dignity to [the human race]1490-the human race by [his]1489-a man who , whatever his rank may be virtues , and not be content to live in an effeminate court on the traditions of past grandeur . ’ [She]0-i borrowed [her]0-i words from the infamous [Jean - Jacques Rousseau]171-jacques , [the friend of [[her]0-i scarce less infamous father]1492-her scarce less infamous father]1491-the friend of her scarce less infamous father — nay ! [I]0-i will say it,—if not [her]0-i words , [she]0-i borrowed [her]0-i principles . And [[my]0-i son]3267-my son to request [her]0-i to marry [him]3267-my son ! “ ‘ It was [[my]1494-you father]309-my father ’s written wish , ’ said [Clement]195-pierre . “[1494-you] ‘ But did [you]1494-you not love [her]0-i ? [You]1494-you plead [[your]1494-you father]1495-your father ’s words,—words written twelve years before,—and as if that were [your]1494-you reason for being indifferent to [my]0-i dislike to the alliance . But [you]1494-you requested [her]0-i to marry [you,—and]1496-you,—and [she]0-i refused [you]1494-you with insolent contempt ; and now [you]1494-you are ready to leave me,—leave [me]0-i desolate in [a foreign land]1497-a foreign land — ’ “ ‘ Desolate ! [[my]1494-you mother]312-my mother ! and [the Countess Ludlow]172-the countess ludlow stands there ! ’ “[1494-you] ‘ Pardon , [madame]1370-madame ! But [all the earth]1499-all the earth , though it were full of kind hearts , is but a desolation and a desert place to [a mother]1500-a mother when [[her]1500-a mother only child]1501-her only child is absent . And [you]1494-you , [Clement]195-pierre , would leave [me]0-i for [this Virginie,—this degenerate De Crequy]1502-this virginie,—this degenerate de crequy , tainted with the atheism of [the Encyclopedistes]1503-the encyclopedistes ! [She]0-i is only reaping some of the fruit of the harvest whereof [[her]0-i friends]1504-her friends have sown the seed . Let [her]0-i alone ! Doubtless [she]0-i has [friends]3176-friends — it may be [lovers]1506-lovers — among [these demons , who , under the cry of liberty]1507-these demons , who , under the cry of liberty , commit every licence . Let [her]0-i alone , [Clement]195-pierre ! [She]0-i refused [you]195-pierre with scorn : be too proud to notice [her]0-i now . ’ “ ‘ [Mother]173-mother , [I]1508-your mother can not think of [myself]1508-your mother ; only of [her]0-i . ’ “[1508-your mother] ‘ Think of [me]0-i , then ! [I]0-i , [[your]195-pierre mother]1508-your mother , forbid [you]195-pierre to go . ’ “ [Clement]195-pierre bowed low , and went out of [the room]489-the room instantly , as [one blinded]3272-one blinded . [She]173-mother saw [his]195-pierre groping movement , and , for an instant , [I]195-pierre think [her]173-mother heart was touched . But [she]173-mother turned to [me]195-pierre , and tried to exculpate [her]173-mother past violence by dilating upon [her]173-mother wrongs , and they certainly were many . [The Count]3273-the count , [[her]173-mother husband ’s younger brother]3274-her husband ’s younger brother , had invariably tried to make mischief between [husband]1084-husband and [wife]1083-wife . [He]3273-the count had been [the cleverer man of the two]3277-the cleverer man of the two , and had possessed extraordinary influence over [[her]173-mother husband]729-her husband . [She]173-mother suspected [him]3273-the count of having instigated that clause in [[her]173-mother husband]729-her husband ’s will , by which [the Marquis]3280-the marquis expressed [his]3280-the marquis wish for the marriage of [the cousins]3281-the cousins . [The Count]3273-the count had had some interest in the management of [the De Crequy property]3283-the de crequy property during [[her]173-mother son]991-her son ’s minority . Indeed , [I]195-pierre remembered then , that it was through [Count de Crequy]174-the count de crequy that [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow had first heard of [the apartment which [we]3286-we afterwards took in [the Hotel de Crequy]3287-the hotel de crequy]3285-the apartment which we afterwards took in the hotel de crequy ; and then the recollection of a past feeling came distinctly out of the mist , as it were ; and [I]195-pierre called to mind how , when [we]3286-we first took up [our]3286-we abode in [the Hotel de Crequy]3287-the hotel de crequy , both [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow and [I]195-pierre imagined that the arrangement was displeasing to [[our]3286-we hostess]3289-our hostess ; and how it had taken [us]3286-we a considerable time before [we]3286-we had been able to establish relations of friendship with [her]173-mother . Years after [our]3286-we visit , [she]173-mother began to suspect that [Clement]195-pierre ( whom [she]173-mother could not forbid to visit at [[[his]195-pierre uncle]3290-his uncle ’s house]3291-his uncle ’s house , considering the terms on which [[his]195-pierre father]3292-his father had been with [[his]195-pierre brother]3293-his brother ; though [she]173-mother [herself]173-mother never set foot over [[the Count de Crequy]174-the count de crequy ’s threshold]3294-the count de crequy ’s threshold ) was attaching [himself]195-pierre to mademoiselle , [[his]195-pierre cousin]3260-his cousin ; and [she]173-mother made cautious inquiries as to the appearance , character , and disposition of [the young lady]3296-the young lady . [Mademoiselle]168-virginie was not handsome , [they]3297-they said ; but of a fine figure , and generally considered as having a very noble and attractive presence . In character [she]168-virginie was daring and wilful ( said one set ) ; original and independent ( said another ) . [She]168-virginie was much indulged by [[her]168-virginie father]1460-her father , who had given [her]168-virginie something of [a man]725-a man ’s education , and selected for [her]168-virginie intimate friend [a young lady below [her]168-virginie in rank , [one of [the Bureaucracie]3302-the bureaucracie]3301-one of the bureaucracie , [a Mademoiselle Necker , daughter of [the Minister of Finance]3304-the minister of finance]3303-a mademoiselle necker , daughter of the minister of finance]3300-a young lady below her in rank , one of the bureaucracie , a mademoiselle necker , daughter of the minister of finance . [Mademoiselle de Crequy]168-virginie was thus introduced into [all the free - thinking salons of [Paris]22-paris]3305-all the free - thinking salons of paris ; among [people who were always full of plans for subverting society]3306-people who were always full of plans for subverting society . ‘ And did [Clement]195-pierre affect [such people]3307-such people ? ’ [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy had asked with some anxiety . No ! [Monsieur de Crequy]167-monsieur de crequy had neither eyes nor ears , nor thought for anything but [[his]167-monsieur de crequy cousin]3260-his cousin , while [she]168-virginie was by . And [she]168-virginie ? [She]168-virginie hardly took notice of [his]167-monsieur de crequy devotion , so evident to [every one else]3309-every one else . [The proud creature]3310-the proud creature ! But perhaps that was [her]168-virginie haughty way of concealing what [she]168-virginie felt . And so [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy listened , and questioned , and learnt nothing decided , until one day [she]169-madame de crequy surprised [Clement]195-pierre with the note in [his]195-pierre hand , of which [she]169-madame de crequy remembered the stinging words so well , in which [Virginie]168-virginie had said , in reply to a proposal [Clement]195-pierre had sent [her]168-virginie through [[her]168-virginie father]1460-her father , that ‘ When [she]168-virginie married [she]168-virginie married [a man]725-a man , not [a petit - maitre]1488-a petit - maitre . ’ “[195-pierre] [Clement]195-pierre was justly indignant at the insulting nature of the answer [Virginie]168-virginie had sent to a proposal , respectful in its tone , and which was , after all , but the cool , hardened lava over a burning heart . [He]195-pierre acquiesced in [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother ’s desire , that [he]195-pierre should not again present [himself]195-pierre in [[[his]195-pierre uncle]3290-his uncle ’s salons]1511-his uncle ’s salons ; but [he]195-pierre did not forget [Virginie]168-virginie , though [he]195-pierre never mentioned [her]168-virginie name . “ [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy and [[her]169-madame de crequy son]991-her son were among the earliest proscrits , as [they]3315-they were of [the strongest possible royalists]3316-the strongest possible royalists , and [aristocrats]1465-aristocrats , as it was the custom of [the horrid Sansculottes]3318-the horrid sansculottes to term [those who adhered to the habits of expression and action in which it was]3319-those who adhered to the habits of expression and action in which it was [their]3315-they pride to have been educated . [They]3315-they had left [Paris]22-paris some weeks before [they]3315-they had arrived in [England]9-england , and [Clement]195-pierre ’s belief at the time of quitting [the Hotel de Crequy]175-the hotel de crequy had certainly been , that [[his]195-pierre uncle]3290-his uncle was not merely safe , but rather [a popular man with [the party in power]3322-the party in power]3321-a popular man with the party in power . And , as all communication having relation to [private individuals of a reliable kind]3323-private individuals of a reliable kind was intercepted , [Monsieur de Crequy]167-monsieur de crequy had felt but little anxiety for [[his]195-pierre uncle]3290-his uncle and [cousin]3325-cousin , in comparison with what [he]195-pierre did for [many other friends of very different opinions in politics]3326-many other friends of very different opinions in politics , until the day when [he]195-pierre was stunned by the fatal information that even [[his]195-pierre progressive uncle]3327-his progressive uncle was guillotined , and learnt that [[his]195-pierre cousin]3260-his cousin was imprisoned by the licence of the mob , whose rights ( as [she]1358-his mother called them ) [she]1358-his mother was always advocating . “[195-pierre] When [I]0-i had heard all this story , [I]0-i confess [I]0-i lost in sympathy for [Clement]195-pierre what [I]0-i gained for [[his]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother . [Virginie]168-virginie ’s life did not seem to [me]0-i worth the risk that [Clement]195-pierre ’s would run . But when [I]0-i saw [him]195-pierre — sad , depressed , nay , hopeless — going about like [one oppressed by a heavy dream]1513-one oppressed by a heavy dream which [he]195-pierre can not shake off ; caring neither to eat , drink , nor sleep , yet bearing all with silent dignity , and even trying to force a poor , faint smile when [he]195-pierre caught [my]0-i anxious eyes ; [I]0-i turned round again , and wondered how [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy could resist this mute pleading of [[her]169-madame de crequy son]991-her son ’s altered appearance . As for [[my]0-i Lord [Ludlow]92-lady ludlow and [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven]1515-my lord ludlow and monkshaven , as soon as [they]1515-my lord ludlow and monkshaven understood the case , [they]1515-my lord ludlow and monkshaven were indignant that [any mother]1516-any mother should attempt to keep [a son]1517-a son out of honourable danger ; and it was honourable , and a clear duty ( according to [them]1515-my lord ludlow and monkshaven ) to try to save the life of [a helpless orphan girl]1518-a helpless orphan girl , [[his]195-pierre next of kin]1519-his next of kin . None but [a Frenchman]1520-a frenchman , said [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord , would hold [himself]1520-a frenchman bound by [an old woman]299-an old woman ’s whimsies and fears , even though [she]299-an old woman were [[his]1520-a frenchman mother]1358-his mother . As it was , [he]1520-a frenchman was chafing [himself]1520-a frenchman to death under the restraint . If [he]1520-a frenchman went , to be sure , [the wretches]1524-the wretches might make an end of [him]1520-a frenchman , as [they]1524-the wretches had done of many [a fine fellow]1525-a fine fellow : but [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord would take heavy odds , that , instead of being guillotined , [he]3081-my lord would save [the girl]545-the girl , and bring [her]545-the girl safe to [England]9-england , just desperately in love with [[her]545-the girl preserver]1528-her preserver , and then [we]1529-we would have a jolly wedding down at [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven . [[My]0-i lord]3081-my lord repeated [his]3081-my lord opinion so often that it became a certain prophecy in [his]3081-my lord mind of what was to take place ; and , one day seeing [Clement]195-pierre look even paler and thinner than [he]195-pierre had ever done before , [he]195-pierre sent a message to [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy , requesting permission to speak to [her]169-madame de crequy in private . “ ‘ For , by [George]126-george ! ’ said [he]195-pierre , ‘ [she]169-madame de crequy shall hear [my]195-pierre opinion , and not let [that lad of hers]3329-that lad of hers kill [himself]195-pierre by fretting . [He]195-pierre ’s too good for that , if [he]195-pierre had been [an English lad]3330-an english lad , [he]195-pierre would have been off to [[his]195-pierre sweetheart]3331-his sweetheart long before this , without saying with [your]126-george leave or by [your]126-george leave ; but being [a Frenchman]1520-a frenchman , [he]195-pierre is all for [AEneas]176-aeneas and filial piety,—filial fiddle - sticks ! ’ ( [[My]195-pierre lord]3081-my lord had run away to [sea]3221-sea , when [a boy]3335-a boy , against [[his]3335-a boy father]3292-his father ’s consent , [I]195-pierre am sorry to say ; and , as all had ended well , and [he]3335-a boy had come back to find both [[his]3335-a boy parents]3337-his parents alive , [I]195-pierre do not think [he]3335-a boy was ever as much aware of [his]3335-a boy fault as [he]3335-a boy might have been under other circumstances . ) ‘ No , [[my]195-pierre lady]336-my lady , ’ [he]195-pierre went on , ‘ do n’t come with [me]195-pierre . [A woman]3339-a woman can manage [a man]725-a man best when [he]725-a man has a fit of obstinacy , and [a man]725-a man can persuade [a woman]3339-a woman out of [her]3339-a woman tantrums , when all [her]3339-a woman own sex , [the whole army of [them]3344-them]3343-the whole army of them , would fail . Allow [me]195-pierre to go alone to [my]195-pierre tete - a - tete with [madame]1370-madame . ’ “[195-pierre] What [he]1531-he said , what passed , [he]1531-he never could repeat ; but [he]1531-he came back graver than [he]1531-he went . However , the point was gained ; [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy withdrew [her]169-madame de crequy prohibition , and had given [him]1531-he leave to tell [Clement]195-pierre as much . “ ‘ But [she]1370-madame is [an old Cassandra]3346-an old cassandra , ’ said [he]195-pierre . ‘ Do n’t let [the lad]3210-the lad be much with [her]1370-madame ; [her]1370-madame talk would destroy the courage of [the bravest man]3348-the bravest man ; [she]1370-madame is so given over to superstition . ’ Something that [she]1370-madame had said had touched a chord in [[my]169-madame de crequy lord]3081-my lord ’s nature which [he]195-pierre inherited from [[his]195-pierre Scotch ancestors]3350-his scotch ancestors . Long afterwards , [I]169-madame de crequy heard what this was . [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott told [me]169-madame de crequy . “[169-madame de crequy] However , [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord shook off all fancies that told against the fulfilment of [Clement]195-pierre ’s wishes . All that afternoon [we]1533-we three sat together , planning ; and [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven passed in and out , executing [our]1533-we commissions , and preparing everything . Towards nightfall all was ready for [Clement]195-pierre ’s start on [his]195-pierre journey towards [the coast]1534-the coast . “ [Madame]169-madame de crequy had declined seeing any of [us]1533-we since [[my]1535-my lord]3081-my lord ’s stormy interview with [her]169-madame de crequy . [She]169-madame de crequy sent word that [she]169-madame de crequy was fatigued , and desired repose . But , of course , before [Clement]195-pierre set off , [he]195-pierre was bound to wish [her]169-madame de crequy farewell , and to ask for [her]169-madame de crequy blessing . In order to avoid an agitating conversation between [mother]393-mother and [son]3353-son , [[my]1535-my lord]3081-my lord and [I]1535-my resolved to be present at the interview . [Clement]195-pierre was already in [his]195-pierre travelling - dress , that of [a Norman fisherman , which [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven had , with infinite trouble , discovered in the possession of one of [the emigres who thronged [London]2-london]3356-the emigres who thronged london , and who had made [his]195-pierre escape from [the shores of [France]45-france]3357-the shores of france in this disguise]3355-a norman fisherman , which monkshaven had , with infinite trouble , discovered in the possession of one of the emigres who thronged london , and who had made his escape from the shores of france in this disguise . [Clement]195-pierre ’s plan was , to go down to [the coast of [Sussex]49-sussex]3358-the coast of sussex , and get some of [the fishing or smuggling boats]3359-the fishing or smuggling boats to take [him]195-pierre across to [the French coast near [Dieppe]50-dieppe]3360-the french coast near dieppe . There again [he]195-pierre would have to change [his]195-pierre dress . Oh , it was so well planned ! [[His]195-pierre mother]1358-his mother was startled by [his]195-pierre disguise ( of which [we]3362-we had not thought to forewarn [her]1358-his mother ) as [he]195-pierre entered [[her]1358-his mother apartment]3363-her apartment . And either that , or the being suddenly roused from the heavy slumber into which [she]1358-his mother was apt to fall when [she]1358-his mother was left alone , gave [her]1358-his mother manner an air of wildness that was almost like insanity . “[1535-my] ‘ Go , go ! ’ [she]1535-my said to [him]1536-him , almost pushing [him]1536-him away as [he]1536-him knelt to kiss [her]1535-my hand . ‘ [Virginie]168-virginie is beckoning to [you]1536-him , but [you]1536-him do n’t see what kind of a bed it is — ’ “ ‘ [Clement]195-pierre , make haste ! ’ said [[my]1535-my lord]3081-my lord , in a hurried manner , as if to interrupt [madame]1370-madame . ‘ The time is later than [I]1535-my thought , and [you]1536-him must not miss the morning ’s tide . Bid [[your]1536-him mother]1508-your mother good - bye at once , and let [us]3367-us be off . ’ For [[my]1535-my lord]3081-my lord and [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven were to ride with [him]1536-him to [an inn near [the shore]3370-the shore]3369-an inn near the shore , from whence [he]1536-him was to walk to [his]1536-him destination . [[My]1535-my lord]3081-my lord almost took [him]1536-him by the arm to pull [him]1536-him away ; and [they]3081-my lord were gone , and [I]1535-my was left alone with [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy . When [she]169-madame de crequy heard the horses ’ feet , [she]169-madame de crequy seemed to find out the truth , as if for the first time . [She]169-madame de crequy set [her]169-madame de crequy teeth together . ‘ [He]1536-him has left [me]1535-my for [her]169-madame de crequy ! ’ [she]169-madame de crequy almost screamed . ‘ Left [me]1535-my for [her]169-madame de crequy ! ’ [she]169-madame de crequy kept muttering ; and then , as the wild look came back into [her]169-madame de crequy eyes , [she]169-madame de crequy said , almost with exultation , ‘ But [I]1535-my did not give [him]1536-him [my]1535-my blessing ! ’ ”[1535-my] CHAPTER VI . “ All night [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy raved in delirium . If [I]0-i could [I]0-i would have sent for [Clement]195-pierre back again . [I]0-i did send off [one man]3372-one man , but [I]0-i suppose [my]0-i directions were confused , or they were wrong , for [he]1536-him came back after [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord ’s return , on the following afternoon . By this time [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy was quieter : [she]169-madame de crequy was , indeed , asleep from exhaustion when [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow and [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven came in . [They]3374-they were in high spirits , and [their]3374-they hopefulness brought [me]0-i round to a less dispirited state . All had gone well : [they]3374-they had accompanied [Clement]195-pierre on foot along [the shore]3370-the shore , until [they]3374-they had met with [a lugger]3376-a lugger , which [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord had hailed in good nautical language . [The captain]3378-the captain had responded to these freemason terms by sending [a boat]3379-a boat to pick up [[his]3378-the captain passenger]3380-his passenger , and by an invitation to breakfast sent through a speaking - trumpet . [Monkshaven]166-monkshaven did not approve of either the meal or the company , and had returned to [the inn]3381-the inn , but [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord had gone with [Clement]195-pierre and breakfasted on board , upon grog , biscuit , fresh - caught fish—‘the best breakfast [he]195-pierre ever ate , ’ [he]195-pierre said , but that was probably owing to the appetite [his]195-pierre night ’s ride had given [him]195-pierre . However , [his]195-pierre good fellowship had evidently won [the captain]3378-the captain ’s heart , and [Clement]195-pierre had set sail under the best auspices . It was agreed that [I]0-i should tell all this to [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy , if [she]169-madame de crequy inquired ; otherwise , it would be wiser not to renew [her]169-madame de crequy agitation by alluding to [[her]169-madame de crequy son]991-her son ’s journey . “[0-i] [I]0-i sat with [her]1537-she constantly for many days ; but [she]1537-she never spoke of [Clement]195-pierre . [She]1537-she forced [herself]1537-she to talk of the little occurrences of Parisian society in former days : [she]1537-she tried to be conversational and agreeable , and to betray no anxiety or even interest in the object of [Clement]195-pierre ’s journey ; and , as far as unremitting efforts could go , [she]1537-she succeeded . But the tones of [her]1537-she voice were sharp and yet piteous , as if [she]1537-she were in constant pain ; and the glance of [her]1537-she eye hurried and fearful , as if [she]1537-she dared not let it rest on any object . “ In a week [we]3385-we heard of [Clement]195-pierre ’s safe arrival on [the French coast]3386-the french coast . [He]195-pierre sent a letter to this effect by [the captain of [the smuggler]3388-the smuggler]3387-the captain of the smuggler , when [the latter]841-the latter returned . [We]3385-we hoped to hear again ; but week after week elapsed , and there was no news of [Clement]195-pierre . [I]1537-she had told [Lord Ludlow]99-lord ludlow , in [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy ’s presence , as [he]99-lord ludlow and [I]1537-she had arranged , of the note [I]1537-she had received from [[her]169-madame de crequy son]991-her son , informing [us]3385-we of [his]195-pierre landing in [France]45-france . [She]169-madame de crequy heard , but [she]169-madame de crequy took no notice , and evidently began to wonder that [we]3385-we did not mention any further intelligence of [him]195-pierre in the same manner before [her]169-madame de crequy ; and daily [I]1537-she began to fear that [her]169-madame de crequy pride would give way , and that [she]169-madame de crequy would supplicate for news before [I]1537-she had any to give [her]169-madame de crequy . “[1537-she] One morning , on [my]0-i awakening , [[my]0-i maid]1538-my maid told [me]0-i that [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy had passed a wretched night , and had bidden [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott ( whom , as understanding French , and speaking it pretty well , though with that horrid German accent , [I]0-i had put about [her]169-madame de crequy ) request that [I]0-i would go to [[madame]1370-madame ’s room]1540-madame ’s room as soon as [I]0-i was dressed . “ [I]103-mrs. medlicott knew what was coming , and [I]103-mrs. medlicott trembled all the time [they]3391-they were doing [my]103-mrs. medlicott hair , and otherwise arranging [me]103-mrs. medlicott . [I]103-mrs. medlicott was not encouraged by [[my]103-mrs. medlicott lord]3081-my lord ’s speeches . [He]3081-my lord had heard the message , and kept declaring that [he]3081-my lord would rather be shot than have to tell [her]169-madame de crequy that there was no news of [[her]169-madame de crequy son]991-her son ; and yet [he]3081-my lord said , every now and then , when [I]103-mrs. medlicott was at the lowest pitch of uneasiness , that [he]3081-my lord never expected to hear again : that some day soon [we]3394-we should see [him]3081-my lord walking in and introducing [Mademoiselle de Crequy]168-virginie to [us]3394-we . “[103-mrs. medlicott] However at last [I]0-i was ready , and go [I]0-i must . “ [Her]1541-she eyes were fixed on the door by which [I]103-mrs. medlicott entered . [I]103-mrs. medlicott went up to the bedside . [She]1541-she was not rouged,—she had left it off now for several days,—she no longer attempted to keep up the vain show of not feeling , and loving , and fearing . “[103-mrs. medlicott] For a moment or two [she]1541-she did not speak , and [I]0-i was glad of the respite . “ ‘ [Clement]195-pierre ? ’ [she]1541-she said at length , covering [her]1541-she mouth with a handkerchief the minute [she]1541-she had spoken , that [I]1541-she might not see it quiver . “[1541-she] ‘ There has been no news since the first letter , saying how well the voyage was performed , and how safely [he]1542-he had landed — near [Dieppe]50-dieppe , [you]1541-she know , ’ [I]0-i replied as cheerfully as possible . ‘ [[My]0-i lord]3081-my lord does not expect that [we]1544-we shall have another letter ; [he]3081-my lord thinks that [we]1544-we shall see [him]1542-he soon . ’ “ There was no answer . As [I]0-i looked , uncertain whether to do or say more , [she]1541-she slowly turned [herself]1541-she in bed , and lay with [her]1541-she face to the wall ; and , as if that did not shut out the light of day and the busy , happy world enough , [she]1541-she put out [her]1541-she trembling hands , and covered [her]1541-she face with [her]1541-she handkerchief . There was no violence : hardly any sound . “[0-i] [I]0-i told [her]1541-she what [[my]0-i lord]3081-my lord had said about [Clement]195-pierre ’s coming in some day , and taking [us]1544-we all by surprise . [I]0-i did not believe it [myself]0-i , but it was just possible,—and [I]0-i had nothing else to say . Pity , to one who was striving so hard to conceal [her]1541-she feelings , would have been impertinent . [She]1541-she let [me]0-i talk ; but [she]1541-she did not reply . [She]1541-she knew that [my]0-i words were vain and idle , and had no root in [my]0-i belief ; as well as [I]0-i did [myself]0-i . “ [I]1541-she was very thankful when [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott came in with [Madame]169-madame de crequy ’s breakfast , and gave [me]1541-she an excuse for leaving . “[1541-she] But [I]0-i think that conversation made [me]0-i feel more anxious and impatient than ever . [I]0-i felt almost pledged to [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy for the fulfilment of the vision [I]0-i had held out . [She]1541-she had taken entirely to [her]1541-she bed by this time : not from illness , but because [she]1541-she had no hope within [her]1541-she to stir [her]1541-she up to the effort of dressing . In the same way [she]1541-she hardly cared for food . [She]1541-she had no appetite,—why eat to prolong a life of despair ? But [she]1541-she let [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott feed [her]1541-she , sooner than take the trouble of resisting . “ And so it went on,—for weeks , months — [I]103-mrs. medlicott could hardly count the time , it seemed so long . [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott told [me]103-mrs. medlicott [she]103-mrs. medlicott noticed a preternatural sensitiveness of ear in [Madame de Crequy]169-madame de crequy , induced by the habit of listening silently for the slightest unusual sound in [the house]3047-the house . [Medlicott]103-mrs. medlicott was always [a minute watcher of [any one whom [she]103-mrs. medlicott cared about]3397-any one whom she cared about]3396-a minute watcher of any one whom she cared about ; and , one day , [she]103-mrs. medlicott made [me]103-mrs. medlicott notice by a sign [madame]1370-madame ’s acuteness of hearing , although the quick expectation was but evinced for a moment in the turn of the eye , the hushed breath — and then , when the unusual footstep turned into [[[my]103-mrs. medlicott lord]3081-my lord ’s apartments]3400-my lord ’s apartments , the soft quivering sigh , and the closed eyelids . “[103-mrs. medlicott] At length [the intendant of [the De Crequy estates]1547-the de crequy estates]1546-the intendant of the de crequy estates — [the old man]1450-the old man , [you]1549-you will remember , whose information respecting [Virginie de Crequy]168-virginie first gave [Clement]195-pierre the desire to return to [Paris,—came]51-paris,—came to [St. James ’s Square]52-st. james ’s square , and begged to speak to [me]0-i .
